Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank you and it is my duty and honour to introduce today a bill which is an act to provide for the recall of members of Parliament.
This bill would allow the electors in any federal constituency to recall their member of Parliament by circulating a petition containing the names and addresses of a majority of the voters enumerated in that riding in the previous election. If a recall petition were to be deemed successful by the chief electoral officer a byelection would be called for that seat.
The bill also contains a number of limitations on the recall process designed to avoid superfluous and mischievous employment of this device.
I believe that this bill would do more to ensure democratic parliamentary reform than all the committees this House could put together. It is time that members started representing the interests of their constituents in Ottawa rather than Ottawa's interest in their constituencies.
The passage of this bill may convince them to do just that.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for London-Middlesex for seconding the introduction of the bill.
This is a bill to amend the Corrections and Conditional Release Act and to permit a police officer to arrest a person without warrant for breaching a condition of parole and statutory release.
As you know, Mr. Speaker, and as members of the House and the public are aware, police officers or peace officers can arrest a person who they believe on reasonable and probable grounds is about to breach the Criminal Code.
That is not so with respect to the breaching of a condition of parole and statutory release. They have to go away to try to get a justice of the peace to issue a warrant and then come back to try to find the person. If that happened in a normal situation under the Criminal Code, all sorts of crimes could be committed prior to the obtaining of the warrant. That is the problem here.
Members of the public cannot understand why, when they ask a police officer to arrest somebody who is about to breach their parole, the police officer shrugs and says: "I have to go away". This bill will correct that.

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)) moved
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: PATENT ACT AMENDMENT ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
that Bill C-91, an act to amend the Patent Act, to amend another act in consequence thereof and to provide for other related matters, be read the third time and passed.

December 10, 1992
Government Orders
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to speak in this House to conclude the debate on third reading of Bill C-91.
Since the government announced almost a year ago that it intended to make further amendments to the Patent Act, I think that all concerned have had plenty of time and opportunity to express their opinion.
On our side, we listened very carefully to all the opinions expressed, whether here in this House or in other forums outside. We have taken account of them to a large extent in drawing up and improving the bill, especially in the amendments we tabled that were adopted last night.
I think that the time has come for members of this House to conclude and settle the debate, for the greater benefit of the Canadian economy and also Canadian consumers.
On several occasions since June, I have had an opportunity to explain the main objectives of Bill C-91 and I would like to come back to them a little.
First, Bill C-91 is meant to continue the major undertaking of modernizing Canadian intellectual property legislation, which began some years ago. In the present economic context where knowledge and innovation are the watchwords, I think that everyone will agree that it is an essential element of our competitiveness.
Our purpose is also to align our laws with those of most of our international competitors, so that Canada can provide the same benefits and be as attractive as other countries in terms of international trade and investment.
This bill will help us to stimulate research and development in Canada, as well as growth in a leading-edge sector.
With Bill C-91, we also wanted to strengthen consumer protection, so that consumers can continue to obtain patented medicine at reasonable prices. I think that all Canadians are entitled to that.
To attain these main objectives, we basically are proposing two new provisions. First, Bill C-91 proposes the abolition of the compulsory licensing system for patented drugs. Let me emphasize that Canada is currently the only country in the industrialized world
applying this system. Holders of pharmaceutical patents will thus be assured of the 20-year protection that is already provided to all other patent holders in the Canadian economy.
Second, the bill increases the powers of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board. These new powers will enable the board to more effectively control the prices of both existing and new patented medicines. The bill provides for fines and prison terms for those who do not comply with the board's orders.
We remain convinced that Bill C-91 strikes a balance between two government objectives: economic growth and consumer protection.

Hon. members will remember the first step was made when Bill C-22 was passed in 1987. Today we can say, without exaggeration, that the impact of the 1987 amendments has been extremely positive, both for economic growth and job creation and for Canadian consumers, as far as patented drugs are concerned.
It seems appropriate, in the circumstances, to look back on the process that started in 1987. The innovative sector committed itself at the time-provided the amendments to Bill C-22 were passed-to doubling its spending on research and development as a percentage of sales from 5 per cent at the time to 10 per cent by 1996. The industry had set a time frame of about 10 years, or actually nine.
However, last year, five years ahead of schedule, the commitment to increase research levels was practically met. We have every reason to expect that this percentage will increase substantially in the years to come, provided we align our intellectual property policies with those of other industrialized countries.
Since 1987, the innovative sector of the pharmaceutical industry has spent more than $1 billion on research and development. Investment in basic research has more than tripled, rising from $30 million to $94 million between 1988 and 1991.
In 1991 alone, innovative pharmaceutical companies invested $376 million in R and D, an increase of 23 per cent over the previous year. This is just for 1991: $376 million. Between 1988 and 1991, the increase in R and D spending was an impressive 113 per cent, the highest in any Canadian industry. Not bad. Sometimes people say: "Look, we give industry a chance and it is not responding". In this case, I think we can say we were on target.
December 10, 1992

The innovating sector in the pharmaceutical industry is a very dynamic one today and employs more than 18,000 people in Canada. This has meant a very significant increase in the number of researchers as well as in new drug innovation and development here in Canada.
We know that pharmaceutical research, and I would even say research in general, needs a critical mass. We need to create an environment where enough researchers are brought together in one place so that this sector can develop.
I have personally visited companies where considerable investments involving hundreds of millions have been made over the years and I met young researchers who had left us. They had been trained here in Canada, and we know how much money and energy we put into our education system. We trained these researchers who have doctorates, Ph.D.s, and they went to Switzerland, to California and other parts of the United States to work. To earn their living in a leading sector, these Canadian brains had to go to the United States. These people came back. Just in the company that I visited, I believe that from 15 to 20 people had come back to work here in Canada for years to come.
Meanwhile, with the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, we were able to keep the price of patented medicine at a very reasonable level. In fact, between 1987 and 1991, the price of existing patented medicine rose at an average annual rate of 2.9 per cent, well below inflation for the same period, which was around 4.4 per cent. In actual figures, this means that prices in general rose at the fairly low rate of 4 per cent, but drug prices rose even less. Today, drugs cost less in constant dollars than they did five years ago. That is astounding. This has happened in few other sectors.
Despite this undeniable progress, we are still behind our international competitors in the amount of intellectual property protection given to the pharmaceutical sector. Indeed, our present system is by far the least generous of the industrialized countries. Our compulsory licensing system not only discriminates against drug patents-just look at the number of years-it also discourages investment in R and D and new drug innovation and development in Canada.
Government Orders
What kind of investment can we expect in this country if a company that does not do basic research can sit and wait until another company has spent 10 years and hundreds of millions of dollars on research to develop a new drug? All it has to do is sit and wait until the drug comes on the market, copy it, wait two or three years for the copy to be approved, and then put it on the market, not at 10 per cent but 80 per cent of the other company's price. That is the kind of choice Canada has to make. We have a choice. Do we want a country that encourages copiers or do we want a country that encourages research, that encourages our budding scientists who are still in school and who in some cases spend 15 to 20 years of their lives getting an education? Would you rather we told those people: "There are no jobs for you in Canada. You better go to California to get a job. All we do here is copy. We will leave innovation to people in other countries. We will let them do the creative work, and you can come and copy what they do". No, Canada can do better than that.

We cannot tolerate a situation that for Canadians means the potential loss of productive jobs in a leading sector so important to our future. It is time to correct this situation and to encourage new investments in research and development in Canada. It is important to offer new export markets for Canadian products so that we can be more competitive internationally.
By adopting C-91, this House will be committing itself to this path of innovation and progress essential to the Canadian economy. Since last January innovative pharmaceutical firms have already announced additional investments totalling some $635 million by 1996.
When the innovative pharmaceutical industries committed $1 billion dollars, they delivered. Now they announce another $600 million investment. That is $1.7 billion of investment. It is a lot of money. This is over and above the approximately $2 billion the brand name industry will invest in research and development by 1996. This sharp increase in research activity means job creation. Notably it will provide better opportunities for our researchers so they will not be forced to leave the country to find employment that corresponds to their education and ability.

December 10, 1992
Government Orders

What we are talking about here are high quality, high paying jobs that generate employment in related fields.
It is estimated that a single job in the scientific sector generates a dozen more. That is one the reasons why it is so important to stimulate research activity in this country. These companies need services and supplies. The economic spin-offs and the multiplier effect on jobs are vital for Canada.
Increasing research is essential for our universities and hospitals which are actively involved in research, especially in the health sector. I think we all realize that research requires a lot of money and drug companies invest in research. For instance, the University of Alberta has developed exceptional expertise in clinical research in recent years. In British Columbia they are now looking at the possibilities, while companies are also looking at the maritimes. Hundreds of millions of dollars are involved. We are going to develop this industry over time, not the way some people in the opposition would like to see us do, which would make us a nation of copiers, a nation of people without a desire to innovate.
In the New Democratic Party, they say: "No, we do not have the resources. It is not our market. Let other people innovate in other countries, and once they have a successful drug, we will go and copy it". It is easy. All we have to do is copy the drug. We do not have to invent it. Let these young people go down to the United States to work for the multinationals. Let them innovate down there, and we will do the minor stuff like copying. We will copy the pills and try and put them on the market. We do not want that. Canadians can do better than that.

speechtext: Of course, they can.

speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: PATENT ACT AMENDMENT ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Canadians can do better than that. This is not a nation of copiers. Canadians are innovators. Canada is the best country in the world. I have confidence in these young people and I am glad to see some of them here today. I am confident that these young people will be even better than we are. They will invent even more than we have, because that is the way of the future.
We do not have to be satisfied with crumbs, as those people would have us believe. The future is ours, and I am not afraid of it. Canadians are the best in the world and we have to prove it in fields like this one.
In 1991, the innovative drug sector spent $84 million in universities and hospitals doing medical research. Passing this bill will of course consolidate and even increase this essential role that our research and training institutions play. Canada has an increasingly solid nucleus of internationally known researchers and institutions in the field of medical research. It is very important to maintain and develop this nucleus. That is precisely what this bill will help achieve.
We have people like Dr. Labrie, who does basic research on prostate cancer at Laval University. This is very important, because a few years from now, as many as one out of three Canadians may get cancer. That is where we should put our money, because it will save hundreds of thousands of lives in this country. That should be our focus. We must help the people who work in our research centres, hospitals and universities across Canada.
Improving patent protection will also offer an incentive for Canadian-owned companies to develop their own patented drugs. Eventually they could also obtain exclusive research mandates from the big drug companies. That is the way to go. We have to start somewhere to create the critical mass we need.
Eliminating compulsory licensing will stimulate research activity, which will have a very positive impact in our competitive position internationally. The resulting new pharmaceutical products developed in this country will lead to increased sales on foreign markets because of the international exclusivity granted companies located in Canada. This means increased exports in a rapidly expanding sector of our economy.
Furthermore, Bill C-91 will promote research on new treatments for chronic diseases and help reduce health care costs in the long run. In fact, as new drugs appear on the market, they may reduce the need for operations and prolonged hospital care.
December 10, 1992

Recently, I read an article in a medical journal about a drug that will soon be on the market and can be used instead of surgery to deal with prostate-related problems. This means saving thousands of dollars that would otherwise be spent on surgery and hospital care. Imagine the tremendous saving in health care costs. It is incredible. Let us remember we stand to benefit in the long term.
[English ]
The bill before us is also based on an obvious concern for fairness. It is fair that the pharmaceutical products sector be entitled to the same patent protection that is given in all other sectors of the economy. I would even say that this is of special importance to pharmaceutical companies which often invest between 10 and 12 years in research, not to mention significant financial resources in developing new medicines.
Critics of Bill C-91 focus of course on the price of patented medicines. You would have to agree, Mr. Speaker, that the opposition has changed its argument very little since the debate on Bill C-22 in 1987. It even called to its aid Mr. Ralph Nader, a citizen of a country where the cost of prescription medicines is 32 per cent higher than in Canada. Mr. Nader would clearly be far wiser to defend American consumers than spend his time here with the critic of the Liberal Party.
What did Mr. Nader say? Basically he said the same thing as he did in 1987 which was that increased protection for intellectual property in the pharmaceutical field will create an explosion in the price of prescription drugs.
[ Translation ]
However, as I said earlier, the price curve of patented drugs since 1987 clearly indicates that the opposition and even Mr. Ralph Nader, at the time, were wrong. They were wrong then and they are still wrong today.
Perhaps I may recall that since 1987, we have had a quasi-judicial agency which has proved its mettle in monitoring the price of patented drugs. I am of course referring to the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, whose powers will be enhanced under the new legislation. The board will thus be able to provide all Canadian
Government Orders
consumers with even more effective price control. These new powers will authorize the board to order a reduction of prices it considers too high. It will also be able to impose fines of up to $100,000 a day to compensate for previous overpricing and to discourage such practices.
The board's orders will have the same force and effect as a Federal Court order. This means that non-compliance with these orders is equivalent to contempt of court, which carries particularly severe penalties. I am convinced that these new provisions will assure Canadian consumers, of reasonable prices, like those they have had since 1987.
At that time, and this is the other aspect, the generic industry said that Bill C-22 would mean death for it. Surprise, it has continued to grow and everything indicates that this will continue after Bill C-91 is passed.
It has grown so much that a very prosperous Canadian generic drug company has even bought companies in the United States, where they do not have compulsory licensing, the same system we will have here. It is strange how they want to frighten people. I do not know if they think someone is behind me making me do this, Mr. Speaker. I will turn my back to the camera to show that is not so. We do not have to believe that kind of nonsense which was not true in 1987 and is still not true today.
The only difference is that these companies will now be on the same equal footing. They will have to comply with the same rules as the generic industries in other industrialized countries.
In recent months, we have heard some very pertinent observations from consumers, provincial governments, researchers and business people throughout Canada. Of course we will follow up these concerns in the amendments that we proposed which were adopted yesterday.
[English)

In the 1960s a number of reports were commissioned by the Canadian government to try to figure out why the drug prices in Canada were higher than they were in corresponding nations, like the United States or Great Britain or France or Switzerland, or wherever. These studies conclusively proved that drug prices in Canada were much higher than the average, given the comparable state around the world.
The minister opposite says that is not true. I can quote from his own departmental documents. The minister has had 40 minutes to put his case. He has not put it and now he persists in trying to interrupt when the case is being put properly. The minister, if he has so much to say, should have shown up at committee, should have allowed the committee to sit like it wanted to sit, and we would have been able to question the minister longer than 25 minutes, which is the amount of time we got because he did not want the facts to be known.
Back in the sixties the Canadian government reports said that drug prices in Canada were too high. The right hon. member for Vancouver Quadra, a colleague of ours in the House of Commons, at that point, in 1967-68 introduced a bill which set up a system called compulsory licensing. That system, as set up, recognized that there is intellectual property rights for patents in Canada and around the world, but it recognized that in Canada there is another interest, the Canadian health care system. In order to protect the Canadian health care system, a system called compulsory licensing was set up which allowed competition, because competition moderates prices, it drives prices down.
We embarked on a regime in 1968 which worked. It does not matter who you talk to, you could talk to the Senate subcommittee on aging in the United States, or you could talk to the general accounting office, or even if you talked to departmental officials such as Mr. Eastman, who is the chairman of the PMPRB, everyone says the system works. We can give quotes all day long that he gave.
It is a clear fact known around the world that the system of compulsory licensing, which was introduced into the Canadian health care system by the right hon.
member for Vancouver Quadra, has saved Canadians billions of dollars over the intervening years. Through 1968 and 1987 it saved Canadians billions of dollars in drug costs. When competition goes into the marketplace-and the government's own figures tells us this-the price of the drug goes down generally by about 32 per cent. Canadians benefit. Canadian health care plans benefit. Private insurers benefit because the price goes down.
Everything was working okay. There was not a big problem with generic licensing. However, this bunch opposite came to power in 1984 and after they got in power they just dropped down dead to the American agenda.
It is clear and there have been books written on this, one of the big things the Reagan administration wanted was for Canada to get rid of its system of compulsory licensing.
It had nothing to do with whether or not it was working. It did not care whether or not it was working. What it cared about was kissing up to the Americans down south.

Madam Speaker, nobody on this side and most Canadian people cannot be happy that we are debating this bill this morning. That this bill should be here at all is reprehensible. That it is here because of the pressure of the American government and American multinationals is contemptible. That its inevitable passage has been assured by an abuse of the Parliament of Canada is despicable. Worst of all, that this government should argue that this bill is for the benefit of Canadians is hypocritical. Virtually all Canadians would agree that this is a reprehensible, despicable, contemptible, hypo-
December 10, 1992

critical government that cares not for its people. This is not a government for the people; this is a government for the multinationals.
Its resolve is to further the ideological attack of this government on the Canadian system of social democracy in an effort to pursue a United States agenda to make us more like them, a society with an almost complete lack of sympathy for the poor, the aged, the ill and the disadvantaged.
Canada has become for many nations in the world a model of how we can approach the issue of the cost of drugs and the cost of medicare in a creative and successful fashion. You will recall. Madam Speaker, that in 1969 legislation was introduced in this House to provide for compulsory licensing of patented drugs by generic companies. What Canadians who are listening ought to remember is that before that time the prices of patented drugs in this country were the highest in the industrial world. This government says that legislation was an attack on intellectual property.
What people seem to forget is that the generic companies did not simply copy the drugs; they paid royalties for them. For those who consider this an attack on intellectual property rights, let us remember that published songs or published books provide royalties to their creators, just as is done in this instance.
So this was not an invasion of the sacred territory of intellectual property. On the contrary, it ensured that competition would be the mechanism assuring reasonable drug prices in this country. We were successful. During all of that time the profits of the drug companies went up and up, as they have continued to do.
In 1986, this government introduced Bill C-22, a bill that extended longer protection to patented drugs. Why did it do that? In the midst of claims that drug prices have not gone up, the government did that in spite of its claim in order, quite specifically, to increase the profits of the drug companies. There is no other reason for having done so. That is perfectly clear.
But we have to remember that Bill C-22 was introduced just before the free trade agreement was signed with the United States. It was a condition imposed by the American government under Ronald Reagan for pursuing negotiations of the free trade deal. I hear the hon. member across the way say: "That is not so". Well, let us just review a couple of facts.
Government Orders
The chairman of the U.S. trade advisory committee was Mr. Pratt. Remember Mr. Pratt, the president of Pfizer? He had a significant role in impressing upon the President of the United States that the Prime Minister had to be told that if he was going to have a deal, he was going to have to give something up.
When the Prime Minister asked what should be given up, the reply was: "Well, how about that generic deal you have going over there, where Canadians actually get drugs for a decent, fair price?" The Prime Minister agreed. Even before the free trade agreement ever entered this place, the deal was cooked.
If there is any doubt about that, let us look at the record out of external affairs. External affairs observed specifically that the trade-off which would have to be made in order to get the free trade agreement would be the elimination, as much as possible, of compulsory licensing of generic drugs in Canada. That is what Bill C-22 did. It provided extended patent protection as was wanted by the American concerns.
Of course, the government did not come in here and say: "Look folks, we have to get this deal so that we can negotiate a worse deal, the free trade agreement". It did not say: "We are going to pass this bill to increase the profits of the multinational pharmaceutical manufacturers that hold the patents". Oh no, it did not say that. What it said was that prices would not increase.
Can you imagine the sophistry of passing legislation in order to increase profits but at the same time telling us that prices will not increase? Why will they not increase? We are going to have a Patented Medicine Prices Review Board which will keep things under control.
Meanwhile, Canadians were promised $1.4 billion in new expenditures for R and D. The then Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs said that we were going to get 3,000 jobs for scientists and technologists out of that and new R and D. That was the justification and argument. What were the real results?
With respect to research expenditures, it has to be admitted that more than $1.4 billion is credited now to the pharmaceutical manufacturers, that is, the multinationals, in terms of increased R and D expenditures.
However, those 3,000 new research jobs did not materialize. The drug companies, the pharmaceutical manufacturers, that is, the PMAC members themselves, said that as of 1990-91 they had created 1,386 new jobs. Let us give them credit for another couple of hundred.

December 10, 1992
Government Orders
They were not those great science and technology jobs. Two-thirds of those jobs were for sales and administration. The research jobs that were created were in fact for that kind of research that is involved in clinical testing by and large.
We do not have and we never will have the basic original research thrust. It will remain in the United States. Not only that, 850 production jobs were lost in that period of time since that legislation was passed. Those are the benefits.
What about prices? The government claims that prices have risen at a rate of 2.9 per cent per year for patented drugs. However, the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board said that new drug prices were from 40 per cent to twice as high as what they were before Bill C-22 was passed.
That is apparently the cause of the results reported by Green Shield. It finds that the costs for drugs have gone up 11 per cent per annum since that time.
Indeed, Stephen Schondelmeyer, whose name has come up previously, said that before Bill C-22 was introduced the Canadian prices for single source drugs were 17 per cent lower than U.S. prices. After Bill C-22, the prices for single source drugs in Canada suddenly rose to 12 per cent higher than in the United States of America. What benefits? The consequences of this were inevitable.
The burden on drug benefit plans has been tremendous. In Ontario, there has been a 50 per cent increase in per capita costs. As a result of that, a number of drugs have been deinsured. The deductibles have been raised for senior citizens in pharmacare plans. Therefore, the impact on seniors, on governments and on the taxpayer is clear: It has been more costly.
Now we have Bill C-91. For those watching this debate. Bill C-91 will essentially double the period of patent protection. It is a direct attack on the generic industry. It has the same purpose as Bill C-22. That is to increase the profits of the drug companies. I repeat that. Let us be clear and unambiguous. There is no other reason for this legislation than to increase the profits of the multinational patent drug makers. What are the benefits that we are going to get from this?
Of course, there was an alliance out there forged by the multinationals, led by the American government to get the rules of GATT changed and the Dunkel provisions to provide increased intellectual property protection. Of course, this GATT proposal has not been approved and it is somewhat weaker than what is provided in the proposed North American free trade agreement.
The North American free trade agreement has the same history as the free trade agreement with respect to the legislation we have before us today. We have another free trade agreement that has a proposal for intellectual property protection, but before that agreement is even ratified, the legislation is in the House. The multinationals said: "Jump," and the government asked: "How high?"
The arguments of the government are again the same as they were for Bill C-22. There is nothing about the increased profits for the drug companies, but again we are going to get more research. Another $400 million or $500 million in new research money is being promised by the PMAC.
Of course, we were promised that drug prices would not increase. The drug prices will increase because profits must increase. What must be understood is that NAFTA and this bill are part of a campaign to make sure that multinational drug profits will increase and be maintained.
It is particularly important that Canada's system be under immediate attack because Canada is a model for the Third World. Without the kind of leadership Canada provides with its system the Third World peoples will not have a chance in fighting the multinationals.
It is important to get this legislation through right now in a hurry. That is why Parliament has been abused. That is why this government has been so anxious to keep a tent over the entire process, to keep people from knowing what is really going on. Unfortunately, people do know what is going on and hold this government in contempt for what it is doing.
It is very important for the multinationals to get the legislation through Parliament and eliminate th# model that we are providing not only for the Third World but also for the United States. The Clinton administration is being made aware that the generic drug system control-
December 10, 1992

Ling drug prices through competition is a reasonable one to be adopted by the Americans as well.
We have Senators Henry Waxman and David Pryor suggesting that Canada has found ways to control prescription drug prices and it is time for the United States to get on the bandwagon. They say this in observing that patented drugs in the United States cost 32 per cent more than they do in Canada even under Bill C-22. Bill C-91 will bring them into line and that is dangerous.
What does Bill C-91 provide? It says in effect that patent protection will be extended from 10 to 20 years to make things simple. It will destroy the system of compulsory licensing. It will virtually eliminate the generic role in providing competition to keep prices low.
As has been mentioned before, it is not enough for the government to rush in with this legislation and get it done now. It is retroactive to December 10, 1991.
Why do you suppose that is so? Because the intellectual property committee advising Carla Hills, the U.S. trade representative, which is dominated by the multinational drug manufacturing representatives insisted that the United States tell Canada to make it retroactive. This is in spite of the fact it will eliminate a number of generic products that were already in the pipeline. How outrageous.
This legislation does not even require that the patent be worked in Canada. The drug does not even have to be manufactured in Canada and there is no provision for the fine chemicals that go into the drug to be made in Canada. There is no real advantage in this bill to Canadians if you look at the balance.
What are they going to get in return? They are going to get another $400 to $500 million in research. They say that drug prices will not increase because the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board will have its mandate for controlling the prices of drugs strengthened.
Come on. This bill is intended to increase the profits of drug companies. We are being told that this institution is going to make sure that does not happen, except there is one fatal flaw. It is very doubtful whether this new power which they pretend to want to confer on this board will be constitutional. There is a very good chance that it would be considered by the courts to be unconstitutional.
What we have here is nonsense because, remember, it is the multinationals that want Bill C-91. They are very clear about another thing. They not only want to get rid
Government Orders
of compulsory licensing. They also want to get rid of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board. Obviously that must be their ultimate goal.
These sneaky devils have said they would put it in the bill, knowing that ultimately it probably will not work but the people will be fooled. There are other ways in which the people are being fooled.
One hon. member said there would be $170 million invested by Merck Frosst in Ontario. That is big stuff. B.C. is not going to be so happy. It is to get $15 million out there if and only if the government puts some money in for the construction of the building. A real advantage.
Let us look at this a little more closely. What the companies are actually promising amounts to not a whole lot. What are going to be the increased costs? The government says it will be $125 million over a decade. There are various figures being bandied about but this much is clear. It is going to cost between $4 billion and $6 billion more in increased drug costs. The governments are going to put in $1 billion in research money. In order to get $1 billion more in research money we are going to take $6 billion or $7 billion out of the pockets of Canadian taxpayers, out of Canadian governments and out of ordinary Canadian people who are ill or need these drugs. We should start back on the civilized path, the civilized vision of Canadians, not the ideological meanness that characterizes this government.

Bill C-22 was a success as anticipated. It has improved the environment for R and D and has favoured job creation while maintaining reasonable drug prices and fostering generic concurrence.
But the world is going through many changes. The global climate surrounding the international drug industry is developing rapidly and Canada must be in the vanguard if we are to continue to lead the way.

Opponents are saying that we are doing this simply for the sake of the multinationals. They are wrong again. We are moving to do this for the sake of Canada and Canadians, for the sake of those who will benefit from new medicines, and for the sake of Canadian scientists and researchers and the growing number of innovative Canadian companies. I will just mention some of them: Quadra Logics in Vancouver, Biomira in Edmonton, Biochem Pharma in Montreal, Allelix Biopharmaceuticals in Toronto and Diagnostic Chemicals in Charlottetown. These are companies which will benefit from this protection of intellectual property. They are Canadian biotechnical companies. These are the companies that are developing the next generation of medicines for the sake of Canadian jobs in a dynamic, high-tech industry. Canadians, whether they are young or old, stand to live longer and more comfortable lives as a result of pharmaceutical innovations.
On the basis of the announcement last January and the tabling of the bill in June, the innovative drug companies have come forward with millions of dollars of new investment that will benefit all regions of the country.
The House may recall that I spoke about $500 million during the second reading of this legislation. That $500 million amount has now increased to $635 million over five years in new manufacturing investments and new research.

Astra is presently looking at various locations in Canada where it could set up a research centre with a world-wide mandate, and that represents an investment of $150 million.

Nordic Merrill Dow and Smith Klein Beechman have each announced investments of $40 million to increase research and development work.
Just three days ago, Ely Lilly announced new investments of $170 million for R and D for high-tech modernization and production.
There is more. Above all, the industry will invest more than $2.5 billion in Canada by 1996. This is good news. The economy needs good news.

I began my remarks by stating that there is a lot of misrepresentation and misinformation in the public domain on this legislation. Let us stop the scaremonger-ing and look at the facts.
First, opponents say that drug prices will soar as a result of Bill C-91. They will not. They have not in the past and they will not in the future. The board, as I said a minute ago, has been given new powers over both new and existing patented drugs. The bill has teeth, it has very sharp teeth. It has some very substantial criminal law penalties that are quite significant.
Seniors have been especially concerned. Again, let us look at reality. Seniors are covered by drug plans in all provinces, and under current provincial plans at least 71 per cent will not pay one penny more as a result of Bill C-91. For the remaining 29 per cent, three-quarters or more of their drug costs are covered by provincial drug plans.
I believe what has caused some of the confusion is that some drug prices are rising faster than the rate of inflation. However, these are not the patented drugs. They have nothing to do with Bill C-91. There was a column in the paper the other day by Dalton Camp. He identified six drugs and talked about how much they had increased. None of these drugs will be affected by Bill C-91.
Eighty per cent of all drugs are not patented and therefore are not subject to any form of price control. The price increases of the remaining 20 per cent, the patented drugs, are under control pursuant to this legislation and Bill C-22 of 1987. These drugs have remained well below the inflation rate, as I mentioned earlier.
The second misconception relates to what my colleague from Windsor has been ranting about just now, which is the cost impact of Bill C-91. The government
has over a period of time, from the ground up, made a drug by drug assessment of the cost increase. It would be $129 million over five years. I want to repeat that, $129 million over five years, roughly $25 million a year, $1 per Canadian per year. That would be offset by the tremendous benefits in new research and development and the new cures. I think that is something that Canadians can endure.
The opponents of this bill have offered cost projections that are all over the map. I listened carefully to my colleague from Windsor's response, but he did not give any substantiation for the wild figures of $4 billion, $6 billion, $7 billion that he threw around. However, Dr. Heinz Redwood, an internationally recognized industry expert, has reviewed the figures that have been developed in the Department of Industry, Science and Technology. He concluded that they are based on substantive analysis. I will quote him. He said: "They are based on acceptable methodology and reasonable assumptions".
He went on to say: "The cost to Canada may well turn out to be lower than forecast, thus adding a safety margin for possible but currently unforeseeable additional costs". Dr. Schondelmeyer, who my friend from Windsor referred to, projects this will cost $7 billion over 17 years. That projection may be sensational and you will probably read about it in the papers tomorrow morning. You will not read about the $129 million.
This is a gross overstatement because the professionals in the department of industry went through his analysis which he produced over the Thanksgiving weekend in the United States. They went over the analysis and pointed out there were drugs in there that were off patent. He was extending terms far beyond what he should have in order to come up with the analysis. What do they come back to? They come back to the $129 million we had developed.
We tabled Dr. Redwood's report in the committee and that is there for all members to see and review. I would like to talk about another element of this and that is the question of drug usage.
Drug costs are driven up more by drug usage, the type of drug, the size and the number of prescriptions. If each Canadian used just one less prescription per year, we would save almost 20 times the additional cost to the drug purchasing system we calculate.
December 10, 1992

Another misconception I want to address is the mistaken notion Bill C-91 will double the patent period for pharmaceuticals from 10 to 20 years. Unfortunately, we heard that again this morning from the hon. member from Windsor. It has been documented time and time again by my colleague, the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
The increase as a result of this bill is three to three and a half years in the market protection provided to these companies. It is not 17, 10 or 20 years or whatever the figures are that get thrown around by the opponents of the bill.
Once the patent does expire, the generic drug companies in Canada will be able to compete openly with the company that invented the medicine, as is the case in any other sector of technology. This legislation is bringing the intellectual property protection for pharmaceuticals in line with what is there for all other types of inventions.
I think this point bears repeating again and again. We are not singling companies out for more favourable treatment, but bringing them into line with other industries.
Opponents say this bill will mean the end to the generic industry in Canada. As I said earlier, the generic industry has grown by 180 per cent since 1987. Our projections indicate in the new environment there is no reason why they should not be able to grow at rates equal to those of the rest of the pharmaceutical industry.
Close to 60 per cent of generic business is now generated from drugs that are already off patent. Furthermore, there are nearly 2,000 off-patent products available to the generics right now that have not been copied by them.
The U.S. generic industry operates in an environment without compulsory licences. It is growing and thriving so much the generic companies have bought U.S. generic companies using the profits they have generated here in Canada. Clearly, there is no reason why this sector should not prosper in Canada.
Yesterday morning Ralph Nader said on Canada AM: "If it ain't broke, why fix it?" These types of opponents ignore the changing realities of the global marketplace.

Mr. Nader talks a great line about all Canada's inventions but he is really saying he would like to see us keep on inventing, but he would not provide the encouragement and protection to the inventors.
He would have us hand these inventions over to countries where there is this protection so they can commercialize the inventions for world markets and take the benefits outside Canada. I do not agree with that. We want to keep the jobs and benefits here in Canada and that is what Bill C-91 is all about.
An international consensus emerged in the GATT about a year ago on world standards for intellectual property. It is critical to Canada's future prosperity that we participate in this consensus. If we do not accept this proposal, Canada will put at risk many of the benefits of the Uruguay round and jeopardize our over-all trade relationships.
These are days of great change in this particular industry. I referred to Business Week, November 16, in my intervention earlier on second reading. I pointed out where a lot of change is happening. Jobs are being lost in other countries. Here in Canada we are gaining these jobs and we are doing so because we do have competitive advantages. We have world class scientists, excellent medical institutions and a reputation of high standards in the area of medicines. We have a tremendous international reputation in the type of health care system we have.

intellectual property and we respect that.

Whatever regime of intellectual property is worked through, this jurisdiction has to be competitive with others in attracting investments.

We want to have a competitive balanced industry which can compete with anyone in the world. We need to have a reasonable regime for the protection of intellectual property and at the same time we have to take our responsibility for trying to manage the costs of a publicly insured plan.

A brief comment, Madam Speaker. The federal government does not have the power constitutionally to control or to influence in a regulatory way retail prices. If there were to be controls, that would be the responsibility of the provincial governments. One of the important influences that we have in this country and one that can serve to help keep retail prices down is through the lists that the provincial governments put out indicating what drugs they encourage people to buy, the so-called formularies.
In this way they can keep an eye on what the retail prices are of the various drugs on the market and encourage people to use those when they are making their purchasing decisions.
This is one of the real strengths we have in Canada. It is one of the ways we want to work together with the provinces where we, through the prices review board, control prices at the manufacturing level and they, working through their formulary and the power that they have through the provincial drug programs, control the price at the retail level.

Madam Speaker, I would like to make a few points with regard to the bill which is before us and its subject matter, but first on the process.
This subject matter is of considerable interest to Canadians in every walk of life: seniors, health care professionals, individuals who have made careers in advocating certain provisions with regard to intellectual property. All have a great deal of concern about this bill and its consequences.
The arrangements which were made at committee were insufficient to deal with the subject matter in any extensive way.
There are those on the opposite side who would conclude because opposition parties sat down and heard a few witnesses that that should be the extent of the debate at committee. In fact members of that committee had hoped to have heard a far larger number of witnesses and wanted to have much more extensive hearings.
The able critic for our party, the hon. member for Dartmouth, repeatedly made that case only to be stonewalled because the government indicated that it was either a few witnesses or no witnesses at all. The motion which went on division was certainly done under duress and we are not being very well served by having a shortened debate on a subject matter which is of considerable interest to Canadians.
Also, I think it would give us a better opportunity. We have heard in this Chamber this morning the charges which were being made by the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs that our facts were wrong. Those of us in opposition made the claim that our facts were right and theirs were wrong. However, that is the essence of parliamentary debate. If we had had longer hearings at committee we probably would have been able to have a much fuller examination of those facts and figures. That is not to suggest or impugn upon anyone who appeared before that committee and gave evidence or testimony.
That is the reality, Madam Speaker. We did not have enough time. We saw at a later stage of the debate of this bill numerous amendments which were not debated. Some of them were adjudicated in this Chamber but again they were not debated because the government was using the guillotine of closure and time allocation to shorten debate on a very important subject.
We are now at third reading on a bill of considerable concern to Canadians and all we have had is a cursory examination of many of the salient parts of this particular bill.
Many of us who have studied this particular issue-I had an opportunity on a previous occasion in 1987 to have such an opportunity to examine this bill-and I want to repeat for the record that I do not concur at all with the findings of the government opposite that we as a
December 10, 1992

separate and independent nation must move toward this new form of intellectual property rights at this time.
I want to be clear. I have great concerns about brand name companies operating in this country. I also have concerns about generic companies operating in this country. For the government of the day to say to Canadians we are now only going to have one industry which it will regulate in its entirety, that being brand name companies, the multinationals, to me is not fair. It is inappropriate and poor public policy.
We are not advocating as a national party, as the member for Dartmouth has indicated time and time again, that we get rid of one at the expense of the other. There ought to be a balance with regard to public policies which we believe compulsory licensing has been able to provide to Canadians over the years.
It was interesting to note that in 1987 the present government House leader, who was the minister responsible. said on the floor of the House of Commons on numerous occasions that the price of drugs in this country would not rise by one red cent. That is what the minister said. I wanted to make this statement, as I know the House would be interested in it.
My colleague, the member for Dartmouth, has repeatedly found information which has been placed on the record that this proposition and thesis just does not stand scrutiny by any test-the test of the opposition, the test of the New Democratic Party or the test of independent third parties. The cost of drugs has increased substantially-
In terms of the government's previous policy, it has not been able to live up to those promises, namely, that prices would not rise one red cent.
However, in this bill it is a little bit different. The government no longer takes out the argument that prices will not rise one cent. It takes out the argument that they are going to rise. Some may say by billions, but they are wrong. It is not billions, they say, it is millions. That is what they say. If you prorate that over a decade it becomes billions quite quickly.
I am astounded to find that the government opposite has seen fit to acknowledge and affirm our claim that prices will rise in this country. The mechanisms it has put
Government Orders
in place to try to deal with that, as again our critic for the Official Opposition, the hon. member for Dartmouth, has repeatedly put, are not effective ways in which to deal with that.
The whole question of compulsory licensing and the rights of those individuals who have intellectual property is an argument that has been made in this House time and time again. We are a party that believes both systems can work in this country. They have been working up to now. They have been saving consumers thousands and thousands of dollars on an individual basis.
In point of fact just the other day I had to get a prescription for my son. I asked the pharmacist, who happens to be a friend, because a brand name was prescribed by the physician, if there was anything in stock equivalent to the brand name. The brand name product was $18.29. The generic product for the same thing, to treat the same illness, was $4.22-a sizeable difference.
I am not here to cry about the fact that I cannot afford the difference between $4 and $18, but the fact of the matter is that there are millions of Canadians who cannot afford that kind of difference. Why would we as a nation throw that system out when it has been balanced?
I know that my time is relatively short. I do want to say that I think there is room and there ought to be room in this country for the two systems of compulsory licensing as well as the brand name drug companies. I think we should keep the system that we have. It has been working well and it has been very effective for Canadians.
This particular piece of legislation does very little in terms of the guarantees for research and development. It does not address in any fundamental way the concerns that we have expressed in terms of pricing. Even the most objective soul in this world-I look to the Chair for guidance in that-would have to agree that a retroactive piece of legislation in itself is damaging.
A retroactive piece of legislation which is financial in its substance is far more damaging to the entire system than probably any other aspect of this particular bill. The government is ready to proceed as Santa Claus will proceed on Christmas Eve as he goes down the chimney and into the living-room to leave the gifts.

December 10, 1992
Government Orders
What a gift. The Conservative government opposite, consisting of the Minister of Justice, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, the Minister of Communications, the Minister of National Health and Welfare-the Prime Minister will not be here shortly- has given this gift to the multinational corporations. It is at the price of taking the hard-earned dollars out of the pockets of ordinary Canadians across this country who work their 40 hours a week, who bring up their children, feed them, put them through school but who now have to be taxed by this government.
It is tax under Bill C-91 in order to facilitate the objectives of the multinational corporations whose primary concern as we all know is the bottom dollar. That is not fair.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to continue debate on Bill C-91 but it seems beyond imagination to understand why there is a debate.
It is very obvious that the people, the consumers in this country, are totally opposed to this bill. I see it in my own riding where I have received many, many letters in opposition and encouraging me on behalf of my constituents and others across Canada to oppose this bill.
It is incomprehensible why this government at this time is having to pass legislation which will bring further benefit to only that sector of our North American economy which at the present time has the highest profit margin. Why is it necessary at this time to give it the opportunity for yet further profit, and not only profit but profit at the expense of every single Canadian citizen and consumer? As well as costing more per person, it puts our health care system in jeopardy.
To quote the Consumers' Association of Canada when it spoke before the legislative committee last week: "With a new administration about to take office in the U.S.. Canada has no reason to proceed with Bill C-91 on the grounds of previous deals with the old U.S. administration to eliminate compulsory licencing".
It said that in view of the fact that the government uses the excuse that it has to put through this legislation at this time. This is in order to comply with rules of the new GATT, which has not yet been approved, and with the rules of NAFTA, which has not been approved either and which we on this side of the House will fight until we get satisfaction that certain minimum standards are met.
When we look at the GATT we see that there is no reason under the articles of GATT that Canada would have to bring in this legislation at this time. There are exceptions expressed explicitly in the GATT legislation which say it is not necessary for Canada to introduce this legislation which would eradicate compulsory licencing in this country.
Furthermore, in NAFTA we see not only the fact that exceptions are allowed, but that our government in negotiating the NAFTA has given a special exception to Mexico that it can have a transition period of eight years before it has to do any alteration to its legislation having
Government Orders
to do with patented medicines, pharmaceuticals and such.
However, in Canada before the trade legislation is enacted, we are bringing forward the legislation today which will have a very negative effect on consumers, on our health care systems, on the generic industry in this country. We are also making that legislation retroactive.
The minister said just a few minutes ago the generic companies have had some benefit since C-22 was passed some years ago, which extended patent protection of the brand name drug companies. But listening to the generic companies it is obvious when C-22 was brought in, it was to be in place until 1997 and would not be altered until there had been a full review. On the basis of that, the generic industry adjusted, made plans and did some research. Yes, they had opportunities to develop their market, but so did the brand name companies equally if not more from that same legislation. Here we are passing retroactive legislation, which will seriously penalize them financially to the point their very existence in this country will be jeopardized.
We stand on this side of the House and make our points. It is constantly stated there is contradictory evidence out there. The fact is this government cut off debate. It cut off once again the voice of the Canadian people who had important things to say about this legislation and very important concerns which we share with them.
The minister said a little while ago anybody who is opposed to C-91 is ignorant of a changing, global marketplace. However, day after day we hear this government using the excuse for our economic woes in this country that we live in a global marketplace. We must be globally competitive. We do live in a globally competitive marketplace, but this legislation only serves to enhance and benefit the multinational corporations. We do have a national agenda which is to represent the best interests of the Canadian people and we do not see it here.

The government says that and promises to go on to another point. It says powers of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board will be increased and there will be more investment in research and development. The minister would say: "Well that is because they are talking about all drugs, not just patent drugs". speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am delighted to be able to rise today and speak on this bill. I will try to deal with some of the issues that have come up in a factual way, one by one, to dispel any doubts or concerns my friends opposite might have.
It is clear to me they are still confused about a number of issues, not the least of which is the difference between procurement and intellectual property. To respond to the question that was inherent in the hon. member's last intervention, we are talking about procurement and not intellectual property when we are dealing with the text she quoted from the NAFTA.
We are dealing with Bill C-91 in the House today which is an act to amend the patent protection act.
I want to begin by going right back to the beginning and asking what is a compulsory licence. A lot of people must be scratching their heads and asking what does compulsory licence mean. If you have a patent does that not give you some protection against infringement on that patent for* number of years? Is that not something

December 10, 1992
Government Orders
everybody would just take for granted? That is what a patent means, is it not?
That is what a patent means in most countries and that is what a patent will mean in Canada after the passage of Bill C-91. Much to my dismay when I came here I learned that currently, a patent can be infringed upon by a special system set up by the Liberal government that provides for something called compulsory licensing. Those words mean we give someone the special privilege to copy a drug while it is still under patent protection.
This bill removes this artificial and damaging provision that has been inserted into our Canadian intellectual property rights. It creates an atmosphere of fairness and a level playing field. It brings Canada into the 21st century with the rest of the G-7 countries and all the rest of the industrial world, with the exception perhaps of India, which is not exactly one of our key trading partners.
It allows us then to be able to attract investment and research and development dollars, which means more jobs for Canadians. They are not just jobs that do not pay well or that are difficult to attract key people to. We are talking about high valued-added jobs that will create opportunities for the development of information based technologies for the future.
The opposition has claimed that somehow the federal government of the day is trying to pass Bill C-91 because it has some nefarious plot. Nothing could be further from the truth.
The fact is, as I have said already, this bill will allow us to attract more investment and it will create more jobs. Since we announced that we were going to proceed with Bill C-91 a year ago-there has been ample time for the country to think about this bill and ample time for debate and discussion, in spite of what my friends opposite have said-we have had announcements of $502 million in investments to the benefit of Canada.
In my own home province, a local company that has been there since maybe the 1960s has doubled its investment by $60 million in the last two or three months. What this means in terms of real jobs and real investment for Manitobans is a spin-off benefit of $145 million a year. That is a tremendously significant boost to the Manitoba economy.
For the agricultural sector, it means jobs. It means opportunities to expand into other areas at a time when traditional agricultural products are difficult to market.
It means that young people coming out of our universities will have an opportunity for employment and will be able to use their degrees and make their degrees worth more in the future. It means that young people coming out of our universities, not just in Manitoba but around the country, will not have to go to the United States or Europe to ply their trade that they have spent so many years developing.
It also means more research. Universities like the University of Alberta, the University of B.C. or even the University of Manitoba, not to mention all the eastern universities, have received something like $84 million in increased research and development funds since 1987 when we passed Bill C-22 limiting the amount of time for compulsory licences. I think even members opposite would admit that this is a very important investment in the future of our young people and the future of our country.
I would also like to point out that the international trade consensus through GATT, which represents 108 countries, is that we must have level playing fields. Regulations such as compulsory licensing are totally unfair. Creating barriers to trade is no longer going to be tolerated in this world.
It is also important to recognize that this is part of the government's over-all plan to create an atmosphere in Canada in which there are jobs available for people, there are investments, there is real trade. Canadians will be far more prosperous in the future because they have a good strong foundation based on common sense rather than government interference.
Since we made the change with the introduction of Bill C-22 back in 1987 there has been a tremendously good pay-back. One of the things that the opposition will claim is that if we pass this bill-and it did this when we were passing Bill C-22-there are going to be huge price increases for drugs. Another claim it made was that the generic companies were going to go crumbling into oblivion because of the passage of Bill C-22, and now with the passage of Bill C-91.

The fact of the matter is that the increase in drug prices has been kept to 2.9 per cent over this period of time because of the PMPRB, the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board. One of the hon. members mentioned a few moments ago that part of my job is to protect consumers. That is precisely what the PMPRB has done since 1987 and precisely what it will continue to do except that now it will have an even better ability to do this than it did before. It will have more teeth. Under the new PMPRB we will be able to send people to prison for up to a year if they do not comply with the policies.
We can fine corporations up to $100,000 a day. These are real penalties. We can order roll backs. We can order a double indemnity if the company refuses to comply with the policies of the PMPRB, and ask it to pay the government double what it would have made in profits over the period of time when it was pricing excessively.
All of these things are issues that are not terribly well received by the innovative companies, by PMAC and others. However, they are things we think we have to do in order to protect consumers because, as the member opposite rightfully said, that is our job.
I would like to point out also that while we have heard a lot about how compulsory licensing has kept prices down there is just not any real evidence to demonstrate it over a long period of time. We have heard the GAO quoted several times and I would like to quote it myself.
The study the United States General Accounting Office conducted pointed out two things. I am going to quote it so that members opposite will understand exactly what I am saying. It said: "Price differentials appear to be driven by factors that influence how much manufacturers can charge for a drug product in the U.S. and Canadian markets. Specifically, manufacturers selling drugs in Canada face two constraints that do not exist in the United States: federal regulations that are designed to restrain introductory prices for new patented drugs as well as price increases for existing patented drugs; and provincial drug benefit plans".
The report then goes on to elaborate on this and mentions that: "The PMPRB appears to restrain Canadian drug prices" and it explains that its mandate is to review patented medicine prices and ensure that they are not excessive.
Government Orders
The key to lower drug prices in Canada has been the PMPRB. With this new bill and the PMPRB's expanded ability to control prices we will be able to have an even stronger handle on the increase in drug prices, particularly with regard to introductory prices.
Provincial formularies play another important role. In fact, the federal government is also examining the possibility of establishing a formulary, which would give us an even stronger handle on what drugs are being sold in our country.
It is not true to say that somehow if this bill passes consumers are going to pay some exorbitant price increase. I want to say to all the people out there, seniors particularly, who have been frightened by the fearmong-ering tactics of some of the opposition that they will not be forced to pay exorbitant price increases for their drugs as a result of Bill C-91.
Most seniors are covered by provincial drug plans, but even for those who are not the price increases they might face are really quite minimal. Overall, no matter who pays for it, the price increases we are facing-the federal government agrees, our officials have told us, that there will be some small price increases despite the PMPRB.
We are looking at $129 million over five years. That is all. That is less than the price of a prescription per year per person. It is about $1 per person per year over that five years. Even if we go beyond the five years to the year 2000 we are looking at an increase over today's costs of about 2 per cent. That is all.
I hope those who are being frightened by the tactics of some who would lead them to believe that prices are going to be out of control after this bill passes will set those fears aside because they are not warranted in any way. The members opposite should be ashamed for using such tactics to make their point.
On the question of price increases, we have heard a lot about Mr. Schondelmeyer who appeared before the committee and talked about numbers that were all over the map. As a matter of fact, some ads were put out. In January some of the generic companies got together and put out an ad that said that prices would increase by $300 million a year. That is a pretty scary figure, but I guess it was not scary enough because two or three months later they came back and said that prices were going to increase by $1 billion a year. They were at the committee

December 10, 1992
Government Orders
a week ago, maybe eight or ten days ago, and guess what. Now the figure was not $300 million or $1 billion.
Now they are talking about $2 billion a year. That is utterly ludicrous. There is just no evidence to support such ludicrous and outlandish claims, but these are the kinds of things that are being said. They are very worrying to people on fixed incomes, and to seniors particularly, who have to rely on the system. They are concerned about costs.
Mr. Schondelmeyer admitted in committee, when I asked him a direct question, that he worked for the Canadian Drug Manufacturers' Association which represents the generic companies who are in opposition to this bill. I do not fault the generic drug companies for that. I can understand that they like things the way they are. They have a special licence to copy patents before they have expired. That is nice.
However, that is limiting the kind of investment we can have. I do not blame them for putting their point forward, but they should base it more on factual evidence than they have.
Then Mr. Schondelmeyer admitted to me in committee that not only was he working for the CDMA but in fact he had pulled his figures together over the Thanksgiving weekend. He told me that. How credible can figures like this be when someone admits that he is already dealing with a vested interest and that he has pulled these figures together over Thanksgiving weekend?
That was not enough. The opposition had to go out and find Ralph Nader. To be frank I thought he had passed on. He has not been a real factor in consumerism in North America for years. But here he was. Those members brought him out of moth-balls, propped him up and got him to say a few things about drug prices in Canada.
I do not know where he got his facts because the things he said were really quite irrelevant. He was reduced to the point of mouthing platitudes. He said: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it". As I mentioned before, the fact of the matter is that compulsory licensing, the regime set up here by the Liberals, is broken. If it had worked, we would have had the kind of investment and development
in the industry that we are getting now and that we have been getting since 1987.
The instant American experts of the opposition do not have the facts at their disposal. I, for one, place a lot more reliance on our federal civil servants. They have taken the time to set up the models and to develop them over a long period of time based on veiy clear empirical evidence. We know that they found that drug prices will rise by only $129 million over five years, $1 per person per year. That is all.
There are a number of other issues I want to get to, but let me just touch on a couple of other things that might be of interest to the members opposite because they obviously lack information or they would not be making such outlandish claims all the time.
Eighty per cent of all drugs in Canada are not affected by Bill C-91. Did you know that? All we are dealing with is 20 per cent of the drug bill. All we are dealing with is 3 per cent of the over-all health care bill. Yet those members are making claims that are so outlandish that we would have to be dealing not only with the drug bill but the entire health care bill not just for Canada, but probably for the United States as well.
The opposition has said that the generic industry will be absolutely destroyed by this bill. It has made that claim several times. It also made that claim back in 1987 when we passed Bill C-22. Let me just share a few facts.

Since 1987, with that nefarious Bill C-22 that it was so worried about, the generic companies' sales have risen by 180 per cent. That is 180 per cent. So much for a suffering industry.

Not only that, but 85 per cent of the generic drug industry is controlled by two companies. It is controlled by just two companies, and they are not public companies. They are not accountable to us. They are not accountable to anybody because the two companies are owned by two individuals. They are private companies. Therefore, we have no idea how much they are making in profits, none whatsoever.
December 10, 1992

Yet we hear across the way that somehow there is something despicable about the fact that these innovative drug companies made 8.3 per cent in profits in the last few years for which I have figures available. They were number six behind a long line of other companies. One of the ones right ahead of them was a mop and brush company.
I am not carrying a brief for the innovative drug companies. All drug companies make a fair profit, and perhaps some even more than a fair profit. However, the fact of the matter is that we do have control over price increases put on the table by the innovative drug companies. We do not have control over the generic companies. The other fact is that the generic companies will be able to continue to copy drugs once this bill has been passed. They cannot copy drugs that are under patent. They will have to wait another three years or maybe three and one-half years until the patent expires, which is only fair under international intellectual property law. That is just the standard across the world.
They will still be able to produce drugs under generic brand names. The fact is that right now only $167 million of their $400 million in sales per year are copied patented drugs. There is something I would like to explain to members opposite if they will be quiet long enough to listen for half a second. Just to go back, the generic companies have sales of about $400 million a year. Of that $400 million, only $167 million are for sale of drugs they have copied that are under patent. The other 60 per cent are drugs they are producing that are off patent already.
That reminds me of something. Going back to Mr. Schondelmeyer, when he put the figures before us he admitted to the committee that the list of the 42 drugs he supposedly used to create his outlandish figure of $1.72 billion was the same as the list we had. We found that half the drugs he had on his list or at least quite a number of them were already off patent. His figures were totally out of line.
The generic companies have done very well in Canada. That is all well and good. It is appropriate. I like to see Canadian companies do well. I might say that they took their profits and invested them in the United States to buy drug companies there.
Government Orders
The bottom line here is very simple. We are passing Bill C-91 because it is good for Canada, it is good for Canadians, it is going to create more jobs, and it is going to create more opportunities. I would like to close by challenging the Official Opposition to tell me, if it comes into government in the next year, whether it will withdraw Bill C-91 and reinstate compulsory licensing. I submit that it will not.

December 10. 1992
