Madam Speaker, before I answer the question or attempt to, I might say that this morning I mentioned that there was $84 million in university investments that had accrued to Canada since 1987.
I would like to correct that. In fact, $84 million is the amount that the innovative companies invested in research and development in Canadian universities in 1991 alone. Since 1987 the total amount to universities and hospitals is about $245 million.
I think that this correction to the record shows that by opening up our trade opportunities, by getting rid of compulsory licensing, we are attracting investment, not just in hard goods, plants and things like that, but in the future of our country through the ability of universities to fund training for students, open up new places, new posts for people who have spent their lives trying to develop the expertise that will allow us to create a very viable and important health industry in Canada.
This is important to the future of all Canadians, particularly those who are out there now worried about their health in the future. There is the development of new drugs and the opportunity to come up with new
Government Orders
cures. These are the things that Bill C-91 is all about and these are the things that will have an important impact on the future of everyone, particularly those who are most at risk.

Madam Speaker, I thought I would say a few words on this bill after listening to the former Minister of Finance and the parliamentary secretary who followed the former Minister of Finance when they mentioned attracting investment.
The former Minister of Finance mentioned encouraging investment, giving incentives to create jobs. It was not that long ago that the former Minister of Finance used those exact same words in this Chamber when the Conservatives first got elected in 1984.
In 1985, the minister stood in this Chamber and used the same words in speaking about scientific research. He said that he was going to continue a program which had been instituted in 1984. As some members might recall, it was the scientific research tax credit program and the minister renewed the government's commitment for another year. It ended in 1986.
The minister stood in this Chamber and talked about creating jobs. He said he would put a moratorium on it but that the government was willing to expand employment in this country. He used exactly the same words as he used here today. The exact same circumstances apply. There is no guarantee in this legislation at all that there will be this investment. There is no guarantee that these jobs will be created.
I thought back to some of the horror stories that came out of the Government of Canada at that time. There was the case of a company that was given a $30 million tax credit to investigate the difference between black and white cows and red and white cows.
Another company was given $1.7 million to investigate the construction of miniature submarines in Canada. Another company was given another $20 million to investigate computers that would actually send things through the air waves between Vancouver and St. John's, Newfoundland without having anything in the telephone lines.
It brought back some memories of the minister standing in this Chamber in 1985 and then again in 1986, announcing the $500,000 capital gains write-off with no strings attached at all. There were no strings attached at all as to what you could use for that write-off.

December 10, 1992

Consequently, for that $500,000 write-off on capital gains, a great many people were claiming profits from the sale of diamonds, fur coats, yachts. In the following year, 1987, the same minister who stood in the House a moment ago and talked about giving breathing room for people to invest money and create jobs removed the surtax on large corporations. He removed that but he also removed the federal tax rebate of $100 per claimant in 1987.
It was the same reasoning. This will create jobs. This will encourage investment. There were no strings attached. There was nothing definitive in writing, saying you have to do this because you must allow these companies the breathing room in order to make their investments and create jobs.
Then Bill C-22 came in. It talked about the same thing we are talking about here today, namely, all of the jobs that would be created, all of this great new investment into our universities and into our schools of higher learning. I remind the minister that the interest on the $2 billion allowed in write-offs for the scientific research tax credit in 1985, not in 1984, and until it stopped in 1986, would have increased the grants to universities and medical research institutions in this country by a full 60 per cent. That is just the interest on the $2 billion.
The concern was trying to find out what the difference was between black and white cows and red and white cows when this would have increased the total amount given to universities in this country by 60 per cent.
The government was not satisfied in 1987 with giving further tax breaks, without having any restriction at all on the $500,000 capital gains, so it went into the diamonds, fur coats and yachts and things like that. Not content with that, the same minister who spoke in this House a moment ago about giving breathing room to create jobs and to have money invested, turned around in 1990 and removed all restrictions on capital gains to anybody who had large amounts of money in private trusts-tens of billions of dollars.
When he made the announcement, it was that this would actually create jobs. This would encourage investment. It all sounds so familiar. The same minister who talked about giving breathing room, encouraging investments and creating jobs turned around last year and changed the entertainment section in the Income Tax Act. What can you do now? It is not good enough to allow some people to write off the cost of a private box in Skydome. Not only can you write off 80 per cent of that, but we will allow to write off 100 per cent of various types of entertainment.
It was on the radio the next morning after the change was made, I believe it was CBC radio, Peter Gzowski's program. They claimed that escort services were now legal because they encouraged investment. They encouraged investors to invest in Canada.
Look at how far we have come with this rationale to allow breathing room, to allow money to be used to create jobs in Canada when our jobs have gone down at the same time those offers were made. There is only one thing we know about this bill, it is going to increase the cost to ordinary Canadians.
There was only one thing we knew about the tax changes that were made in 1985, 1986, 1987, 1989 and 1991. That was they increased the cost to ordinary Canadians and shifted the tax burden from the very wealthy and from the people who have all the money in our society, the international corporations, to our ordinary people.
Today we have gone to the GST. We have now gone to cutting back on unemployment insurance while the government says it is going to give more leeway, more breathing room to these big companies with the hope that they will invest, with the promise that they are going to invest in Canada. There is nothing on stride, nothing on paper at all, just a promise that they are going to invest.
I see that my 10 minutes are up. This is not a very intelligent way to deal with intellectual property.
In conclusion, let me say there appears to be a philosophy underlying all the changes that have been made since 1984. That philosophy has caused a major shift in who is paying the bill. The people we refer to as the middle class and the lower class are paying the bill.

This bill is just another exercise of that authority. The Government of Canada should be ashamed of itself that it is moving it through this Chamber at this speed.

Madam Speaker, I could not agree with the member more when he said this was not an intelligent way to deal with intellectual property. There is no question about it. He is absolutely correct.
On that side of the House for the last two weeks all we have heard is rhetoric and nothing but misrepresentation of fact. They should be ashamed of themselves. They have done that continually on every stage of this bill.
The member should go back to the CBC which can use some good actors. All his speech is intended to do is to raise emotions back home. They have nothing, absolutely nothing, to do with facts. If he had been in the House this morning and had listened to the minister he would understand that what he was saying was absolutely incorrect.
The minister stepped through the numbers with regard to investment in this country as I did last night at report stage on this bill. They are absolutely incorrect. Bill C-22 did exactly what we said it would do. It led to an increase in investment and jobs in this country, something we want. We want to invest in Canada. We want more jobs in Canada. Every time we want to do it and bring in legislation to do it, they want to kill that legislation.
Bill C-91 is going to work as has Bill C-22. They should be absolutely ashamed of themselves for standing in the House and misrepresenting that bill.

Madam Speaker, Canadians must really be scratching their heads. They have all these Conservative members standing in this Chamber and saying two things, every single one of them-cabinet ministers, parliamentary secretaries, members from the east coast, west coast, north coast and central Canada. First-and they always make sure they make this point-they say drug prices have not gone up. They say that drug prices have not gone up. Do they want me to repeat it again? Drug prices have not gone up.
They say: "We are telling the truth". They say: "Here are the facts and figures to show that drug prices have

not gone up". But the minister stated a few moments ago in the Chamber: "We have nothing to do with retail sales. We cannot control that. We cannot monitor that. We cannot monitor the sale of drugs to ordinary Canadians. We cannot do that".
What can they do? They say the price of drugs has not gone up. Then they say: "Oh, we cannot monitor the price of drugs to Canadians, but the prices have not gone up". Why? The minister says it is unconstitutional for them to monitor the retail sale price of drugs in the country. Every Canadian knows the price of drugs has gone up. Where do they live? It cannot be Canada if they say the prices have not gone up.
Not only that, but by the minister's logic there must be something wrong when nine out of ten governments say they are going to pay exorbitant prices under this new bill, that drug prices have gone up, that it is going to cost ordinary taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars, and that the sick and the poor are going to pay.

Madam Speaker, in terms of the dispute that seems to have arisen over prices and why governments cannot control them, is the hon. member aware of a case that arose in the United Kingdom? It involved a fellow by the name of Stanley Adams who had worked in the pharmaceutical industry. He was eventually blackballed by that industry for exposing the pricing practices of drug companies.
I will quote a passage from his book. He said: "Transfer pricing had two advantages. It enabled the company to avoid a large amount of taxation and it allowed them to overcharge without appearing to do so. It worked like this. If a Roche manufacturing company needed to buy raw material from the parent company in Basle to make a finished article, then the raw material was not as you might think, provided at cost or cost plus to a certain fixed level of profit. No. First Roche headquarters had to decide what the world market of that product was or, in other words, just how much they could sell it for and still be sure of having buyers. Then they had no further to look than at different levels of taxation in the various countries and then they had to decide, bearing that in mind, just how much profit they wanted each individual company to show, if any. Once they had made that decision, which obviously depended on how high-"

speechtext: I have to interrupt the hon. member. We did specify that it had to be a very short question and that is becoming a very long comment. A very short comment from the hon. member for Gander-Grand Falls.

I have a very short answer, Madam Speaker. I know exactly what the hon. member was building up to. I did not read it, but I know exactly what this gentleman was building up to. He is building up to explaining why it is that so many of these companies paid not one penny of tax in this country, not one cent. He can explain why Revenue Canada today can tell each member of Parliament that there are individuals who are involved in those companies and make over a quarter of a million dollars a year who do not pay one penny of income tax and why there are so many people in the six figure bracket in this country claiming the child tax credit and the GST rebate because of our system of taxation that favours the very wealthy in this country.

Madam Speaker, it is a great pleasure to follow in debate my colleague, the hon. member for Gander-Grand Falls. For those of us who are new members of this House of Commons in the most recent election, he is someone to watch, to emulate and to consider a mentor in his ability as a debater and in his representation of the people of Newfoundland and the people of Canada.
Bill C-91 in and of itself, the pernicious piece of legislation that it is, is really only a symptom. It is a symptom of a far-reaching disease that is afflicting this country. In the United States it was known as Reaganomics, in Great Britain it was known as Thatcherism. The only thing I think we can call it here is Mulrunacy.
It is not funny. It really is not funny. It is tragic. It is tragic that senior citizens in this country and the parents of young children in this country are going to be sacrificed on the altar of this government's desire to harmonize with the United States of America. All we have heard for the last eight years is harmonize, level playing field, all of these things, that somehow, somebody over there, all of them over there-we could read their lips I suppose-would tell us is a good thing for Canada.
It is interesting that in the United States a little over a month ago, the electorate there decided to change
direction. Would that the electorate in Canada had soon the opportunity to do that very thing.
Why is this bill pernicious? It is pernicious because of the amount of money it is going to cost ordinary Canadians.
We know from the experts in the field that the total savings to Canadians from generic pharmaceuticals in 1992 was about $420 million. Is this a figure to sneeze at? Madam Speaker, would you tell me why the government thinks that this is not something that is good for Canadians, particularly in a recessionary economy, particularly when it has failed so abysmally at all the other promises it attempted to make to the people of Canada about job creation and creating a better future; all the promises with regard to the free trade agreement; all the promises with regard to the economic plans that it had.
This country is littered with the broken promises of this government. This country is soon to be littered with the broken hearts and broken spirits of Canadians who cannot and will not survive because of the hard-heartedness of the government that sits on the other side of this Chamber.
It is not amusing, it is not funny and it is not something that we should heckle about. It is not even something that we should be debating here today. I impute no motives to the members on the other side. I believe and I have always believed that the vast majority of parliamentarians are here to do their best for their constituencies because they believe in public service and because they want to represent their people. However, for those of us on this side of the House there comes a point where you must say: "Stop". You must say: "Look at what it is you are trying to do". You must say to each and every one of them: "Go back into your ridings and talk to the senior citizens. Go back into your ridings and talk to the young parents. Go back into your ridings and talk to the ordinary Canadian on the street. Ask them whether they think this is a good bill". The answer, overwhelmingly, from coast to coast is: "No, no, no".
I do not know how much clearer it can be. The answer equally to this government is that the smoke and mirrors response offered by the minister, by the member for Winnipeg South, by other apologists for this piece of legislation that deserves to go in instantly to the circular file, is this smoke and mirrors response on research and development.
December 10, 1992

We would like to see some hard figures. We would like to see some response as to just how much money is going into research and development when the whole research and development area in this country is at an appalling low level. Again, why is it at an appalling low level? Because of the ghastly policies of this government. Slowly but surely Canadians' birthrights are being sold off. We are losing all of those things that made us uniquely Canadian and we are losing them because of government policy.
It is enough to make you scratch your head and say: "What is the motivation behind this government? What is the reason that it wants to do this? What motivates these people?"
They are masochists.

Well, their masochism, as my hon. colleague from Nepean has suggested, is soon going to come home to roost because the pain that they must so clearly desire will very soon be inflicted upon them.
Again, this is no cause for levity, no cause even for humour. Here we are, two weeks before Christmas, in what is going to be one of the hardest winters in this country since the Great Depression of the 1930s. In a country where people are going to go cold and hungry this winter because of other government policies, in a country where women cannot get justice from their own government in areas of pay equity and sexual harassment, in a country where the government appears to turn a blind eye and a deaf ear to the pleas of its own citizenry for justice, for equality and for a decent standard of living, here we sit in this House of Commons, two weeks before Christmas, in this the hard winter of the hard recession of the 1990s prepared once again to see a bill forced through the House of Commons that is an attack on the people of Canada, that is more particularly an attack on elderly people. Of course when we get to that, who form the majority of the elderly? Elderly women.
There was a joke that said something about women living longer than men. The joke was something about no, it just seems longer. Well, it is going to seem particularly long when elderly women, the poorest of the poor in this country, are hit yet again from another direction.

Some provinces have limited pharmacare for the elderly. That is very true. However, every single day more of those drugs that are covered by provincial programs are removed from the list. The sovereign province of Ontario with a great socialist government put a whole new list out just in the last couple of months.
This is not the kind of Canada that we want. I do not think it is the kind of Canada that the members over there really want. I guess the only thing I can do in all of this is to make a plea to the members over there as we sit here on this Thursday afternoon, on the second last day of what has been one of the most truncated sessions of Parliament in the history of our country, as we sit here following the example of my colleague the hon. member for Dartmouth, and try to stave off what is clearly the inevitable because of the mathematics of government, as we sit here to show to the people of Canada that we on this side of the House find this bill pernicious, that we on this side of the House stand up for the ordinary Canadian, that we on this side of the House have a care for something other than the bottom line of big business and the so-called harmony with the United States of America.
Yes, Madam Speaker, I am winding up. We are all winding up in this House and very soon the pitch is going to be thrown and I know across whose plate it is going to land.

At the very best of times, when you look at what happens vis-a-vis Canada and the United States, we all remember-speaking of George Bush as the hon. member for Winnipeg South did a little earlier today-that Mr. Bush talked about a kinder, gentler America when he was first elected.
Those of us living here said that we already have it. It is called Canada. The great tragedy is that in this Mulrunacy coming from the same fountain as Thatcherism and Reaganomics, we are in great danger of losing this kinder, gentler country. However, there are those of us here who will see that it comes back.

Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to join in the third reading debate on Bill C-91 today.
It is an issue that is dear to my heart, being a 1972 graduate of pharmacy and still a licensed pharmacist in the province of Manitoba. In fact, I spent 12 years behind the counter of a retail pharmacy in Manitoba until I became a member of Parliament in 1984.
I will be right up front to start with. It is largely a question of philosophy. I will be up front about my own feelings. I support this legislation on face value because I believe in intellectual property rights, and I believe in property rights of all kinds.
I can understand the New Democrats being opposed to this bill on philosophical grounds because intellectual property rights and property rights of any kind contradict socialist theory. You cannot practice social engineering in a country when you embrace intellectual and other property rights.
With the Liberals it is a little harder to understand because I know its members believe in research and development, and I know they are not guided by the theories of Karl Marx. It is a little harder to understand other than base crass politics. Simply put, Bill C-91 means Canada can enhance its reputation as a modem, industrial country with a high-tech research capability.
Hundreds of millions of dollars have been invested since the passage of Bill C-22 in 1987. These companies, the brand name companies, the multinationals, and I should clarify this point, may be multinational but they employ 17,000 Canadians in plants and offices across the country.
Government Orders
They are profitable. As I mentioned, they are multinational. I will tell the House this country is in a lot of trouble if we continue to treat profitable businesses with such disdain. That is because governments cannot finance the research and development that needs to be done if we want to be considered a first world modern country.
In fact, industries like the brand name pharmaceutical companies are doing more than half of the R and D in Canada now and governments cannot afford to do it all. If we do not pass this bill we are moving in the wrong direction.
As a matter of fact, Canada is the only industrial country in the world that uses the Patent Act to control drug prices. Other industrial countries all use some form of a prices control board. We have had the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board in place since 1987 with the passage of Bill C-22 and Bill C-91 strengthens the powers of that board. It will have powers to roll back prices, to recapture over-priced products from companies. It will have powers to fine companies and individuals and even powers in extreme cases to imprison people.
In fact, we had the chairman of the board, Dr. Harry Eastman, appear before the committee. He told the committee on more than one occasion that the board has been quite effective in controlling the prices of patented medicines in Canada. It is odd that Dr. Eastman was capable enough to head a Liberal royal commission back in the 1980s but somehow when he becomes chairman of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board and the Liberals oppose a bill, suddenly he is not credible anymore. He told us quite clearly the board is working.
With the hysteria and the fear mongering that has been going on, please excuse me if I do not get overly agitated like some of the speakers in this debate. I was on the committee that dealt with Bill C-22 in 1987 and again with Bill C-91. I heard all the same arguments in 1987 so we have been through all this before. It was not true then and it is not true now.
I will give you three examples of what was said back in 1987 about Bill C-22. The first one was that drug prices would increase dramatically. There are two points I would like to make here.
In the committee the generic drug company representatives told us that Bill C-22 has had no effect on them yet. To claim that we have higher drug prices since 1987,

based on what they told us, cannot be justified. How can we prove that there have been price increases at all?
Based on the report from the Prices Review Board the prices of patented medicine which is the only category of drugs in Canada controlled and monitored by the PMPRB have increased 2.9 per cent per year since 1987, below the level of inflation. That is absolutely true.
We also heard from Green Shield, which is a source often quoted by opposition members. It told us that prices have increased by 11 per cent. That report and the report of the board are not contradictory because they use different criteria and they measure different things. They are not contradictory, something that was confirmed by Dr. Eastman, the chairman.
One of the other criticisms was that there would not be any creation of jobs and research and development would not happen. The companies are five years ahead of schedule. They promised in Bill C-22 to increase research and development to 10 per cent of sales by 1996. They are at 9.6 per cent in 1992. There have been 2,400 jobs created, more created than work in the entire generic industry. What reason do we have to doubt those brand name companies this time?
The third criticism was that the generic industry would somehow be destroyed by Bill C-22. I do not blame the generic drug company representatives and the owners for saying what they are saying because they are trying to protect some massive profits. We are speaking of profits that have gone up 180 per cent since 1987. Two of the top 10 drug companies in Canada are generic companies. There are only two or three other companies in Canada that have sales higher than the highest selling generic company. They are trying to protect their niche of the market and they are trying to protect their profit margin.
One final point on this is that there is a thriving generic industry in the United States and it has a much more restrictive patent policy than we do here in Canada.
We hear a lot from the other side about billions of dollars of costs to our health care system. These claims have been proven to be outrageous, and I will tell you why.
One of the sources being quoted by the opposition, one witness we heard at committee, was a Dr. Schondel-meyer from the United States, a pharmaceutical economist with impeccable credentials. I do not question the man's credentials, he is very knowledgeable. What I do question is his study.
When I looked at his study there were four areas where there were serious mistakes. He uses a list of 42 products. He has wrong patent expiry dates; he has wrong sales figures in at least one case; he has off-patent products on that list, unaffected by Bill C-91; and he assumes a 30 per cent growth rate in sales for these drug products to the year 2010. Anybody in the pharmaceutical industry knows that you cannot predict past five years, and even predicting five years from today is very risky.
We also hear a lot about the costs of pharmaceutical drugs to our health care system in Canada. We hear that it is going to cost our health care system billions of dollars. One thing we do not hear, and one thing that has to be said, is the amount of money saved to our health care system by some of these brand name products. These products, researched and developed by these brand name companies would not exist and there would be nothing to copy if these products were not developed.
The one that is mentioned most often and has been mentioned several times today is a product called Vasotec, made by Merck Frosst and distributed in Canada. It is, I believe, if not the highest selling drug in North America is right near the top. It is used in cardiovascular disease for high blood pressure. There are tens of thousands of people in Canada who die each year from cardiovascular disease, hundreds of thousands in the United States who die each year from CV disease. There has been an independent study done which states Vasotec saves the health care system in Canada $100 million per year because of 58,000 fewer hospitalizations.
There is a new drug on the market called Proscar, which has been on the market a matter of weeks. It is used for prostate enlargement, and 75 per cent of males in Canada will suffer from that illness. This drug will prevent surgery in many cases. We do not yet have the cost figures on this but the savings will be in the millions of dollars as well, because every day that you can prevent
December 10, 1992

someone from going into hospital you are saving a great deal of money.
One other recent case. There is a drug called Zofran which is used for cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. It helps control the nausea and vomiting that go along with chemotherapy, unfortunately, in many cases. This drug is being used in hospitals across the country. There is one hospital in Ontario that is saving $12,000 a day by using this drug which allows patients to go home who otherwise would be in the hospital. It is saving $12,000 a day in one hospital in Canada.
The final classic example, going back several years, was the product Cimetidine used for ulcer therapy, made by Smith, Kline & French, which saved tens of millions of dollars to our health care system.
What I am trying to say, in conclusion, is that in Canada we either have to consider ourselves as a first world, high-tech, modern country or we do not. Of course it is going to cost consumers more money with a policy like this. This type of thing costs money. If every industrial country in the world had a system of compulsory licensing, we would not have the infrastructure in place, we would not have the incentive to develop these new products that give us all a better quality of life and save our health care system millions of dollars.

There is a logical error in the comments made by the hon. member and I would like to ask him about it.
He makes the point that medicine, like any other patented product, deserves to be treated like any other patented product and that, therefore, compulsory licensing or that type of restriction on the rights of the inventors to realize profits on their gain, is unreasonable.
On the other hand, while he is saying that this is an invention like any other and should be treated like any other, he says that we have this board which is going to limit and control prices. Does the government also advocate a control system for the prices of books, or for the prices of zippers, or all the other products that are subject to patent?
It seems to me the very recognition and acceptance of a prices control board is an admission by the government that prescriptions are prescription drugs and patented

drugs are in a special category and should be treated differently from other inventions and that this government is prepared to treat them differently. Therefore, to make the argument that they are just in the same boat is disproved by the very way it treats them.
If it turns out that the prices control board is unconstitutional and is struck down as ultra vires of the federal government, will that member then allow for a system like compulsory licensing to make sure that the consumer does not get ripped off on patented products which are not like any other but which are essential for life and health?

Madam Speaker, there is no error in logic at all. When I began my comments I talked about my personal philosophy and my belief in the protection of intellectual property rights. That belief exists by itself.
I am not the minister and it was not my legislation that was written in 1987, but the prices review board was part of the process and it has been working. Most industrial countries are using a prices review board to control drug prices. It was shown clearly in 1969 when compulsory licensing was put in place that the prices of pharmaceuticals were too high.
However, I think they can be dealt with separately. We can believe in the protection of intellectual property rights. We have the board in place. I support the board because most of the concerns that we hear on this legislation are for costs.
As long as we have the board in place and we can believe what it is saying, because opposition members in the committee did not believe what Dr. Eastman was saying and I cannot think of anyone more reputable or able to lead that board than Dr. Eastman. What he said was not believed. His opinion was that the only problem with constitutionality was controlling the price of drugs at the retail level because there was an overlap with provincial responsibility at that end.
I support the board. I think it is doing good work and I think it will stay in place as long as there are concerns about the prices of drugs.

Madam Speaker, the fact of the matter is that the elimination of compulsory licensing will mean higher drug prices for Canadians. It will mean a direct attack on our Canadian health care system.

If he talked to Canadians, he would find they are concerned that they are going to have to pay higher prices for drugs. Madam Speaker, I will be brief in my response because I know we are almost out of time.
The first question asked was whether drug prices were going to be higher. Yes they are going to be higher. I have looked at the model that the ISTC has put together and it makes a lot of sense. There is a list of drugs affected by Bill C-91.1 have checked that list and it is all valid with the extended patent dates.
There are two assumptions made that I do not agree with. First of all, the department assumes that all products are going to be copied and that is not the case. It is about 1 in 20. The other assumption made is that generics will all enter the market immediately when they are able to. That does not happen either. Usually they wait until it is seen how profitable the product is going to be. Then the product comes on to the market once the licence is in place.
Those figures say $25 million a year for Canadians. That is $1 per year per Canadian. Two cups of coffee a year per Canadian. I think that is a fair price to pay to have the proper system in place to encourage this type of investment.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to participate in the debate on this very important bill.
What we might ask first is why we would be interested in changing the patent legislation particularly as it relates to the drug manufacturing sector.
During the committee process we did hear from a number of witnesses. One that I thought made an excellent presentation was Professor Fernand Labrie from the Laval University Research Centre. I should remind hon. members that Professor Labrie is one of Canada's premier research scientists.
In his brief he gave us a number of comparisons about the economic activity of research and development as it existed in Canada prior to 1987, prior to the current drug patent legislation and also what was going on in other parts of the world and how this legislation would compare to others.
Certainly, there was no doubt about the content of Professor Labrie's argument. He was certainly very supportive of the change. He was supportive of the change because it would bring a much increased economic activity of research and development into the university process. It would create lots of improvements because of the change in patent legislation.
I would like to read one particular paragraph by Professor Labrie. There was a concern about how Canada's patent legislation would then stack up to others. I would just like to quote briefly from his comments on page 14.
It says: "Bill C-91 is the minimum required since the addition of three years of protection for patent products, namely from 7 to 10 years, after approval of the drug remains below the standards accepted by the other members of the group of seven nations. In fact it can be seen on figure 4 that a protection of 14 years is offered in the United States while 15 years are already accepted or planned for the countries of the European common market. So what we are doing is still not achieving the levels that other of our major competitors have, but certainly moving in the right direction".

Then you have to question whether that view is shared and will that economic activity in the form of research activity come to Canada.
The committee received from the Office of the Dean, Faculty of Medicine of the University of Alberta, a very strong endorsement of the whole idea of an influx of research dollars into that particular university. We received another one from the University of Alberta, Department of Medical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases. Again, it was a very strong endorsement of the program as proposed.
We also received endorsement from the Canadian Pharmaceutical Association. Although its brief went into many areas that were really outside what was being reviewed by the committee, I would just like to read one sentence which relates to a comment raised by others about prices. It states: "The association is pleased that the government is proposing to expand the powers of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board".
The prices review board, although part of the legislation, is something not referred to too often at least in the public press as to the ability of government to control the price of patent medicines so that the concern about the economic impact on the health care system is in fact minimized. It certainly supports that particular aspect of it.
McMaster University, Faculty of Health Sciences sent forward a number of reasons that it supports the particular legislation that was before us.
The idea that it is a very centralized support system is somewhat erroneous because we received recommendations of support from the Victoria General Hospital out of Halifax. We received support from the Metropolitan Toronto Board of Trade and the Board of Trade of Montreal.
We received numerous submissions, for example from Quadra Logic Technologies Inc., a group in British Columbia. It says: "My colleagues and I at Quadra Logic Technologies Inc. strongly believe the extra patent protection given pharmaceutical innovators and their inves-

tors would be an important encouragement to the creation of knowledge based jobs in Canada".
We had numerous representations to the committee. Even another group from Dalhousie University sent in submissions of support. Support within the industry that the government says will benefit is certainly there and it is there in spades. I am pleased to see that.
I have to look at this and ask how it affects my constituency. Well, the Liberal Party in my constituency is saying that this is going to be devastating on jobs in my riding. Of course, it is interesting that the Liberal Party representative in my riding, having lived there for I think two or three weeks, knows diddly nothing about the riding because what he is out talking about is the comment: "Your local MP wants to destroy the Canadian pharmaceutical industry and cost up to 100 people in this community their jobs". Obviously he has not done a lot of research.
If he were to do some research in my riding about the jobs that are being protected for the Canadian pharmaceutical industry, he would find a company by the name of Fisons Canada located in Pickering. Since the implementation of the drug patent legislation in 1987, it has invested some $8.5 million in research. It has built a new facility in the town of Pickering. It has increased its employees from 38 to 67 people in the Pickering office itself and has added 27 or 28 people in other parts of Canada. It is a large plant of 50,000 square feet.
So there it is. A Pickering based company has clearly increased its investment in my riding. Of course, he would challenge the people who work there as not being important to the constituency. What he ought to do is learn a little about the constituency.
However, recognizing that he is new and maybe he has not seen that plant, maybe he would like to drive by the Purdue Frederick plant which did not exist in 1987. It is

If that Liberal candidate in my riding had the slightest inclination of being concerned about what goes on in the riding, he might have discovered that.

If he would go over there and have a look at the Sandoz operations, he would see a large manufacturing plant which employs some 260 people that has more than doubled in size since 1987.
It has doubled in size for a number of reasons. One is patent protection. Two is the free trade agreement. Because of the free trade agreement, that manufacturing plant in my riding was able to take a contract from Sandoz U.S. to supply the U.S. market with one of its products. Because of that acquisition of increased economic activity in the Sandoz plant in Whitby, it was then able to go to the Sandoz operations world-wide. It now has a mandate to produce this drug in Whitby, Ontario for the world market.
If my Liberal opponent wants to get out and learn a little bit about the riding, I would be happy to take him when he has a lot of spare time some day after the next election and show him around so he fully understands just what is going on in my riding.
To make it a little more meaningful, we had a problem with the whole issue of pricing and the perception people have. I would like to finally wrap up and say I believe the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board and the powers it has been given will adequately protect the people of my constituency from the drug prices the opposition is espousing as terrible things. In fact, I think they are well protected.
I thank you for this opportunity. I only wish I had more time to give you more information.

Madam Speaker, since the hon. member who just spoke could not remember the name of his opponent in the riding of Ontario but devoted 12 minutes of time to him, I will blurt out his name for him. It is Dan McTeague. Either way he is going to be the member.
The member is confused about prices. He has overlooked the fact prices are already very high so there is a return on investment over a projected period of time, which under Bill C-22 is indicated as seven years. This legislation will extend protection, or a monopoly on those prices for an ever greater period of time.
If the member is really sincere about protecting intellectual property rights he will be honest enough and remind himself and all the members of his caucus such protection already exists for a 20-year period. The portion of the 20-year period that goes beyond the exclusivity of the competition portion is already recompensed by anyone who copies the product to the tune of 4 per cent of sales to allow for competition. It does not deprive them of anything and most, if not all of the investment, is returned before that competition is allowed.
Such is the case in a report published in the Globe and Mail the other day. We learned one of these multinational corporations was receiving 100 per cent return on investment per annum over the course of the last five years for the parent company. They do not need greater incentive. Let us just be honest and say the intellectual property rights are already well protected and we are not talking here about encouraging further investment. The inducements of the marketplace are already there.
We are really looking to reach out further and extend a monopoly, not free marketplace trade, but an inhibition of trade for a longer period of time. Why?

I did know the name of the Liberal candidate. The problem he is going to have is most Liberals in the riding do not know his name because they had to bring him in from Scarborough to fill the nomination.

When the Department of Industry, Science and Technology appeared before the committee to explain the rationale of how it arrived at its price structure and forecast of the costs in the $125 million to $130 million range, the Liberal Party and the NDP spent a whole day questioning the officials on their process and evaluation methods and could not find a loophole.

Madam Speaker, I rise today to oppose Bill C-91, a bill experts say will have us pay anywhere from $1 to $7 billion more for drugs.
This legislation will have disastrous consequences in Canada, in Quebec, especially as regards our health system. Basically, what we have here is legislation which will increase the price of patented drugs in exchange for promises-I want to lay emphasis on the word promises-of job creation in research and development.
I may well be the only member from Quebec to speak against this bill because I tend to agree with The Toronto Star when it says that this government cares more about intellectual property than about people.
I think it is outrageous to be willing to exchange a promise to create jobs, a few menial jobs perhaps, for billions and billions of dollars in giveaways because, from what the federal government has told us, it would seem that we did not get the jobs we had been promised with Bill C-22 when it was passed. We did not get the jobs.
Government Orders
When the government says that the price of patented drugs has not increased-and I want to be precise here-by more than the rate of inflation since Bill C-22 was adopted, that is not true. We have heard the testimonies before the committee on consumer and corporate affairs. We have heard government experts who have told us that they did not have all the answers to our questions, for instance, on the drug called Vasotec. I can tell you that Mr. Eastman, a government expert, said he did not know that drug. Therefore, he could not tell if the price increase was more or less equal to the rate of inflation.
We were left hanging to some extent. We had been asked to take part in this debate by a number of people who may not be important the way ministers or pharmaceutical company officials are, but important people nonetheless. They are constituents from my riding and from other ridings who have responded to our small household mailings and answered the question: Are you for or against this bill on pharmaceutical products?
In my riding of Chambly, I can tell you that the vast majority of those who responded were against. Most of them were middle-class and middle-aged people. These people have told us-I would not want to offend the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs, but I will say it: anyway-that they do not trust at all what the government says about the price of drugs. The people in my riding of Chambly believe, and this is important, that it is dead wrong about the price paid by consumers for drugs when they go to the pharmacy.
To check on the claims made by my constituents, I decided, like a good lawyer, to go to the nearest drug store. There I met an honest pharmacist and I asked him what the price difference really was since the government had legislated on patented drugs. What was the difference? Had prices only increased between 2.7 per cent and 2.9 per cent a year, as the government claimed, since that legislation came in force? The pharmacist replied: "Not on your life, Phil". He then showed me some boxes of medication and said: "Look how much it used to cost and how much it is now". And I must say that I am much more inclined to believe the people in my

I was speaking about the visit I made to the local pharmacy. The pharmacist told me he agreed with many of the people who wrote to me in Chambly that this was a particularly nasty bill.
What about the name?

I will get to the name in a minute. Please hold your horses.
He said he felt if this bill were to go through it would mean a great deal more money spent by Canadians, particularly in my riding, because of the government's gift of millions and according to some experts, billions of dollars to the drug industry.
Vasotec is an example of a drug that is going to be increased in price to the extent it will be very difficult for average Canadians to pay for it. It is used quite extensively. I believe it is either the number one or number three best seller in Canada. It has not been proven by Mr. Eastman to be one of the drugs that did not go higher than the rate of inflation.
Mr. Eastman told us he did not have the information on Vasotec although we had gone to a pharmacy. I think as the minister pores over his notes he will remember that if he was there that day. I believe my colleague from Surrey North actually gave the material to the minister's people as well as to Mr. Eastman and discovered they did not have the information.
My colleague from Surrey North alleged the price of this one pharmaceutical patent drug had increased far in excess of 2 per cent. I would be glad to have a response from the minister. I believe it had gone closer to 6 or 7 per cent.
I continue on to the question of the difference between the government's figures and the figures presented by independent agencies like Green Shield. Green Shield is an independent agency that deals with drug pricing. It has been doing so for many years on behalf of unions and other people who need to know about that when they are dealing with collective agreements.
It is interesting to note that whenever the government hears that Green Shield is disputing the government figure of 2.9 per cent the federal government automatically says Green Shield is talking about much more than just these patent drugs, that it is talking about all drugs.
Green Shield has said that the increase is close to 6 or 7 per cent if we take out the other drugs. That is incredible. That is not 2 per cent. It is 6 or 7 per cent.

We all tend to have an axe to grind in this House. It is understandable and normal in the context of parliamentary debate to stand up for one's constituency. However, I wonder what constituency this government opposite is representing. Does it represent the seniors? Certainly not because seniors are angry; they are really annoyed about this bill. I cannot understand how members
December 10, 1992

opposite who represent older people can say that people are not angry. That is incredible.
People are angry, and not just older people, but also middle-class people who cannot afford to pay more for Vasotec or other drugs. They are convinced-and there is evidence to back this up-that the price of drugs, of patented drugs, has really been horribly inflated over the past few years.
We are asking this government: Why the rush? Why is it so urgent that we pass this legislation today? What is the hurry? To please GATT of course. But people have asked: Why this urge to please GATT just now? This thing has worked well for us in Canada. It has even helped keep our health system healthy. However, if this bill were to be passed today, I really think that would strike quite a blow to our health system.
I am probably the only member from Quebec to speak and vote against this bill. I know that many Conservative members from Quebec and Bloc Quebecois members will call me an enemy of Quebec. I hate this sort of criticism because it is divisive. People are being labelled as either friends or enemies of Quebec. Let me tell you that I am as much a Quebecer as the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and that I am no enemy of Quebec. But I am definitely an enemy of exploitation, and I suggest that this bill does exploit the most vulnerable people in our society.
I know there are plenty of statistics supporting both sides. The government has quoted figures indicating that all kinds of jobs will be created. Mr. Chairman, I want to speak briefly to this bill, S-16, and in doing so thank especially the member for Lambton-Middlesex for their co-operation as well as the critics from the other parties.
The United Grain Growers had its origin in the Grain Growers Grain Company which was formed by farmers in the Sintaluta district of Saskatchewan in the early 1900s. The United Grain Growers, Limited was an amalgamation of the Grain Growers Grain Company along with some other farmer organized co-ops. It was incorporated under a special act of Parliament in 1911. Today it is a co-operative with some 86,000 members and $400 million in assets. It operates 266 elevators across
Bill read the third time and passed.
December 10, 1992

the four western provinces as well as two terminals at Thunder Bay and one in Vancouver.
In addition to the handling of grain, UGG sells fertilizer, seed and other farm supplies and publishes farm papers like Grain News and The Country Guide.
As hon. members know, the world marketplace for grain is not easy. In the face of subsidized competition, any and all deficiencies in the handling and transportation of grain to tide water must be examined. Like the other handlers, United Grain Growers faces major capital expenditures to modernize its grain handling facilities. Significant investments will be required in order to build new elevators and upgrade many of the older facilities so they can be made to work effectively in linking producers to their offshore customers.
To this end, over 95 per cent of the shareholder delegates at the United Grain Growers 86th annual meeting last month approved a capital reorganization and restructuring plan. Since that date, November 4, 1992, the company has moved swiftly to meet the requirements of Parliament to allow this petition to be considered. The problems are UGG is not now legally empowered to enter into underwriting agreements with the investment banking community nor can the company issue shares to take advantage of the investment interest that has already been expressed.
Further, the capital construction plans of the company contemplate attracting equity capital for investment. If UGG were not able to enter into an underwriting arrangement, this would cause delays that would impact on the company's cash position and ultimately the investment program in grain handling infrastructure.
It is for this reason that timely consideration of the bill has been requested. UGG was incorporated by an act of Parliament. The general laws of Canada do not allow the company to reorganize itself. The changes must be approved by Parliament.
The changes are these. They are embodied in Bill S-16. The legislation will cause UGG's capital structure to change in the following ways. First, it will allow for new capital investment needed. Second, it will allow for the allocation of the existing equity and patronage
Private Members' Business
dividend credits on a fair and equitable basis. Third, it will allow for the preservation of the existing representative membership structure. Fourth, it will preserve farmer control, as 12 of the 15 members of the board of directors will be farmers.
Once this reorganization is complete, United Grain Growers intends to make an initial public offering of its common shares in order to raise the capital necessary for expansion and modernization of its infrastructure.
Finally, this legislation will enable United Grain to better serve its customers throughout western Canada. In the larger picture it will help Canada's competitive position in world agricultural markets.
I therefore thank all members present for supporting this motion in regard to Bill S-16 which will enable the restructuring of United Grain.

Mr. Chairman, we would like to lend our support to the hon. member's statement this afternoon on Bill S-16, the United Grain Growers restructuring bill. It is a private member's bill from the Senate.

It will maintain the control of the grain producers who now are involved in this organization. It will allow them to go ahead with capital construction in the summer of 1993.
The United Grain Growers have had some 25 information meetings throughout the west. I understand there is broad support from their 86,000 members across the three prairie provinces to see this capital reorganization of the company go ahead. Then it can raise funds in the capital markets of the country and go ahead with its capital construction projects in the summer of 1993. We support the speedy passage of this bill.

Mr. Chairman, on behalf of my party and myself I would also like to indicate that we intend to support this legislation. It is obviously something the farmers that have been involved in the United Grain Growers have thought through veiy carefully. The United Grain Growers really pioneered the whole concept of the organization of co-operatives on the prairies that very firmly entrenched farmer control of grain handling over a number of generations now.
This present structure envisions that farmers will continue to maintain control of that structure but that might well prove difficult to do once the present course of action has been embarked on.

speechtext: The House resumed from Monday, November 23, consideration of the motion of Mr. Ferguson that Bill C-226, an act to reduce automotive pollution, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Natural Resources envelope.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak on Bill C-226 this afternoon, an act to reduce automotive pollution.
The Department of Transport administers emission regulations for motor vehicles under the Motor Vehicle Safety Act but it does not regulate fuels. The Minister of the Environment has authority to regulate certain aspects of fuel quality under the Canadian Environmental Protection Act. I would like to say a few words about motor vehicle pollution and the relationship between vehicles, fuel and emission controls.
The North American automobile industry is gearing up to manufacture vehicles meeting new stringent United States emission standards beginning in 1994. These low emission vehicles are designed around fuel available in the United States.
Considerable work is being done by vehicle manufacturers on more advanced emission controls planned on the U.S. Clean Air Act. Some of these involve reformulated gasolines and other alternative fuels.
Motor vehicle emissions depend on the fuel that is used and how the vehicle and its emission controls process that fuel. To achieve much lower vehicle emissions than we have today, we need better fuels as well as better vehicle emission controls. In some cases, the fuel constituent itself is harmful, as was the case with lead. In addition, certain fuels and fuel additives can damage emission control devices.
One of the reasons against the use of lead in gasoline is that it in a sense poisoned the exhaust catalyst so that they are no longer effective in controlling emissions. Canadians are very conscious of the need to protect the environment, and the government takes very seriously its responsibility to regulate emissions from the ever-growing fleet of motor vehicles.
Under the impetus of government emissions regulations, the auto industry has made impressive improvements in the unit emissions from passenger cars. Today emissions of hydrocarbons and carbon have been reduced by over 95 per cent from the uncontrolled vehicles of the 1970s while emissions of oxides of nitrogen have been cut back by 70 per cent and further reductions will occur in the mid-1990s.
Canadian regulations are planned to have the same stringent vehicle emission controls as those in the United States. One step toward bringing new emission regulations on stream is to make detailed amendments
December 10, 1992

to the Motor Vehicle Safety Act. This step is currently in progress through Bill S-8, the Motor Vehicle Safety Act.
Meanwhile, there is a memorandum of understanding with vehicle manufacturers that cars sold in Canada between 1994 and 1996 will meet the new standards. These further reduce emissions of hydrocarbons by 29 per cent and of oxides of nitrogen by 60 per cent from the already low values.
Since Canada represents 8 per cent of a largely integrated U.S.-Canadian market supplied by an international industry, manufacturers have little difficulty providing Canada with the same emission controls as used in the United States even if they are stringent controls.
As I said, an important part of vehicle emission control is the fuel. Canadian gasoline is not always the same as that available in the United States. We have our own feedstock and refineries, and marketing of the final product is relatively local rather than being international or even national.
As the U.S. tightens its regulations on automotive gasoline and as the vehicle manufacturers develop emission controls based on fuels of a certain standard, the availability of compatible fuels in Canada becomes a very important issue.
In addition to any direct emission effect of a fuel it is an issue for manufacturers that their vehicles give a satisfactory lifetime performance in Canada.
It is important, therefore, for the successful outcome of the emission control negotiations and regulations under the Motor Vehicle Safety Act that compatible fuels are available and continue to be available in Canada.
The two items addressed by Bill C-226 are oxygen content and another very difficult phrase known as MMT or methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl. The oxygen content of gasoline is important for low emissions of carbon monoxide and can be raised by gasoline additives, one being ethanol about 10 per cent by volume, to achieve the suggested oxygen level. However, there are important questions in developing an oxygen level less than the number in Bill C-226.
Private Members' Business
MMT is not allowed by regulation under the United States Clean Air Act. It is widely used in Canada and is a potential issue for vehicle manufacturers. They are faced with a different gasoline than used for 92 per cent of the vehicles in the Canada-U.S. fleet. It is a very significant thing that the gasoline we use in Canada with MMT is not allowable for 92 per cent of the fleet produced in an integrated fashion by Canada and the United States. Ninety-two per cent of that is represented by the U.S. market.
Evidence of direct harmful effects, or of significant effects to vehicle emission control systems is not yet clear. The Ethyl Corporation, maker of the MMT additive, continues research and representations in Washington with a view to having MMT allowed in the U.S.
Environment Canada with its responsibilities under the Canadian Environmental Protection Act and Energy, Mines and Resources Canada are both well aware of these issues. These departments along with Transport Canada are in close contact.
Fuel standards are extremely technical in nature and it is vitally important to the environment that gasoline should be compatible with vehicle emission controls. Comprehensive fuel regulations need to be developed and kept up to date with rapidly changing technology.
Whereas the intent of Bill C-226 to foster cleaner gasolines has merit, the mandates it contains to bring about changes in fuel quality are not appropriate primarily of course for the marketing reality that I mentioned earlier of 92 per cent of the integrated market being in the United States where MMT is not allowable.
There is, however, an established process for considering new fuel specifications and this should be followed in the quest for cleaner fuels. Federal departments, the Canadian General Standards Board, provincial governments, and the oil refining and vehicle industries are all following this subject very closely. A workshop was convened in October by government departments and the Canadian Petroleum Products Institute to discuss the opportunities and the costs associated with gasoline reformulation. This workshop involved the numerous parties which would be affected by the fuel changes, including the motor vehicle industry and environmental organizations.

December 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
To ensure proper consideration, therefore, of the complex technical and environmental health and economic issues involved in this whole question of fuels and contaminants, the established process is the one that we on this side feel should be encouraged.

Mr. Speaker, I do not know where the member for Fredericton-York- Sunbury gets his information from, but it seems to me he is sadly unaware of the fact that MMT, which he discussed in his intervention, has been banned in the United States since 1978. Therefore, it is very unlikely it will ever be allowed again as he implied in his speech.
We have before us for discussion today a very reasonable and interesting proposal, namely a bill that would reduce automotive pollution. It is proposed by the member for Lambton-Middlesex. It is a bill that commands attention and respect. It will have three results if implemented. It would ban a substance that is detrimental to health, namely MMT, which is an additive to gasoline. It would reduce certain emissions that cause various forms of air pollution. Also, it would promote the use of a renewable source of energy called ethanol which is produced from com and would add considerably to the agricultural economy.
The title of the proposal alone, namely an act to reduce automotive pollution, should be enough to generate positive supportive interventions on the part of backbenchers of all parties. Only a Conservative government would argue against it. This is what we have seen throughout the debate on this measure.
The last time we debated this bill on November 23, the government trotted its big artillery into the Chamber which revealed in the course of the discussion the weakness of the arguments.
Let me quote, for instance, the parliamentary secretary for national health and welfare, as reported at page 13764 of Hansard. She said:
The elderly may be susceptible to brain damage from manganese
but we lack the knowledge about both susceptibility and differences
in metabolism in this particular group.
Manganese is what we are talking about when we mention MMT. The parliamentary secretary for national health and welfare seemed blissfully unaware of an
Environmental Protection Agency decision which made a specific reference to manganese containing the substance MMT as follows:
During EPA's consideration of the 1990 ethyl submission, EPA's office of research and development conducted a manganese inhalation risk assessment based on the available data which found that:
- because of the considerable uncertainties and data gaps in the available information it is not possible to conclude definitely that the increased use of MMT as a fuel additive will (or will not) increase public health risk.
Obviously the Environmental Protection Agency did not rule out MMT as a risk to public health. This is a point which seems to have escaped the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare as well as the member for Fredericton-York-Sunbury.
Then on November 23 we had an intervention by an esteemed colleague whom I admire and respect, the member for Parry Sound-Muskoka. He said in his intervention that ethanol increases nitrous oxides. That is true, but ethanol blends reduce carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon emissions while an increase in nitrous oxides takes place. The over-all effect is a net reduction of ozone-forming acids. That is a point that has escaped the spokespeople on the government side.
The member for Parry Sound-Muskoka went on to quote the Ethyl Corporation. It is tantamount to putting the fox in charge of the chicken coop to start quoting the Ethyl Corporation on matters related to pollution.
There was an interesting quotation in the speech by the member for Parry Sound-Muskoka when he said:
Our interventions to regulate fuel quality should only be where no other mechanism will achieve the desired result.
He invoked the idea that voluntary co-operative efforts of the fuel suppliers and motor vehicle manufacturers should take place. He remarked:
Market based approach has proven effective and therefore the government will continue to support and facilitate these efforts.
When it came to acid rain the member for Parry Sound-Muskoka was a very active participant and promoter of government intervention. One wonders why the same approach should not apply when it comes to gasoline additives and automotive pollution.
December 10, 1992

The member for Parry Sound-Muskoka went on to
say:
The benefits of removing MMT should be addressed and development of a comprehensive strategy on fuel quality should take place.
After eight years in power it is outstanding that such a declaration should be made, having had five subsequent environment ministers and having had to invoke the necessity of a comprehensive strategy. Where is this strategy, one wonders?
Then we have the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister asking on November 23:
Is it reasonable to pre-empt a comprehensive review of gasoline specifications and environmental impacts under way in Canada?
Which review is that? By whom? With whom? When? Where are the public consultations?
The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister went on to say:
If MMT were not allowed, gasoline costs would increase likely leading to higher gas costs to consumers.
What about the lower gasoline cost in the United States where MMT is not used because it is banned? How do the Americans achieve that miracle of selling unleaded gasoline at lower cost than in Canada and not using MMT?
In essence, to sum up, government members in desperation are using studies by industry. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare admits that the elderly may be susceptible to brain damage. The same parliamentary secretary admits that we have knowledge on manganese and health, but she prefers to shift the onus of proof that manganese is not dangerous to the health community rather than ask industry to prove that MMT is not dangerous. This is a rather absurd position for a parliamentary secretary for health and welfare to take. Instead he should insist that the onus of proof ought to be on industry, that industry should prove that manganese is not harmful to human health.
The member for Parry Sound-Muskoka admits that existing data on MMT are inconclusive. Unfortunately he embraces a double standard, as I mentioned earlier, government intervention on acid rain but not on MMT.
The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister reveals the existence of a comprehensive review of gas specifications taking place but without public consultations.
A very distressing picture is emerging in the debate on this very fine bill of the member for Lambton-Middle-
