sex. We can congratulate him for having taken this initiative. It is good for the farmers. It is good for urban dwellers. It is good for the improvement of air quality and ought to be enthusiastically supported on all sides of the House.

Mr. Speaker,
I welcome the opportunity to speak on this bill today. I will cut my remarks short in order to allow other hon. members who want to speak on the bill the opportunity to speak.
I want to congratulate the member for Lambton- Middlesex on all his hard work and diligence in bringing this matter before the House.
The environment, renewable resources and a viable agricultural community are all extremely important concerns this House has looked at for some time. Ethanol, an environmentally sound product which we have in abundance, really relates to all three of those concerns. Ethanol is good for the environment. It is a renewable resource. It creates an additional market for Canadian agricultural products.
Throughout this debate we have heard government members telling the House that MMT is a safe, environmentally friendly product. They say that many health risks associated with MMT have been greatly exaggerated. For this reason they say they cannot support this bill because it would necessarily ban MMT as a fuel additive in gasoline.
The fact is that the government's position is so entrenched that it does not even test for emission standards. When it tests emission standards the gasoline that it tests does not even have MMT in it. A letter to the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex from the Minister of the Environment dated December 10, 1992 stated:
Thank you for your letter-Hansport Canada's emission testing procedures-The methods it uses in confirmatory emission testing are based on U.S. Environmental Protection Agency certification testing procedures, which are accepted industry-wide, and require that a standardized test fuel be used. That fuel does not contain MMT.
The Minister of the Environment is telling Canadians that we do tests in this country on fuel that does not contain MMT, but everyone driving down the street has MMT in their fuel. This is scandalous. I would gladly put this letter into the record because I think the government has to address the issue seriously. It is a scandalous issue. In addition as spokespersons for the MMT industry, namely Ethyl Corporation, they cannot in good

December 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
conscience support this bill. Make no mistake. The government has made its position very clear.
Contrary to what the hon. member for Calgary Southwest has said-and I have indicated to her that I would be speaking on her comments tonight; I realize she is not in the House-there are many health risks and effects at this particular point in time associated with MMT.
Certainly we are all aware of the neurological effects of the key ingredient manganese. Manganese poisoning can lead to learning disabilities and neurological damage. Ms. Ellen Silbergeld, Environmental Defence Fund, who has a Ph.D. from John Hopkins University, made a written submission to the EPA on July 20,1990, two years ago.
She said:
We know that manganese at high dose is a demonstrated human neurotoxin with persistent and irreversible pathological effects on brain structure and resulting severe impairments in movement and mental state. We do not know what the long-term chronic, low dose consequences of human exposure to manganese are. We do not know a "safe" level of manganese exposure, particularly for those subgroups that may be at increased risk for neurotoxicity (the young and the aged).
The Liberal Party and people on this side of the House have constantly supported the need for Canada to develop alternative fuels. It is good for rural Canada. I think it is good for all. Canadians.
On many occasions we have called on the government to introduce legislation that would seriously support the use of ethanol and ban MMT. We have consistently called on the government to put a program in place for the development of ethanol blended fuels in Canada. All we have seen is government inaction which prompted my hon. colleague from Lambton-Middlesex to bring forward this bill.
Excise tax relief alone is not enough. The $12 million announced last month to encourage production and use of ethanol in Canada is really just a drop in the bucket. It means nothing. It will not help the corn producers in my
area and will not help the com producers in southwestern Ontario.
The ethanol industry does not need more research and development. It needs a serious commitment from this government on ethanol. It needs industry supply for this product and consumer demand for it, which could immediately be realized by banning MMT.
The government needs to take the initiative and then the ethanol plants will be built. That will help Canadian farmers, rural Canada, all Canadians and the Canadian environment.

Mr. Speaker, we must ask ourselves what will be the impact of Bill C-226 on the fuel-producing industry.
Right now in Canada ethanol blended fuel production is around 18 million litres a year and comes mainly from two plants. The first one is owned by Mohawk Oil in Minnedosa, Manitoba and produces 10 million litres a year. The other located in Lanigan, Saskatchewan also produces 10 million litres a year. It is owned by Pound-maker Ethanol Limited. The Lanigan plant, which started production in July 1991, is the first ethanol plant linked to a cattle feedlot in order to take full advantage of co-products. If, by law, gasoline sold in Canada had to have a 3.2 per cent content of oxygen-containing compounds, we would have to produce 10 million litres of ethanol a day, that is close to 200 times our present capacity. In the short term, we probably would have to increase our ethanol blended fuel imports to fill the gap in production.
However, the possible shortage and the initial dependence on imports would be offset by an increase in ethanol production which would greatly help the farm industry. Many interest groups and segments of our society would benefit from ethanol production and its use as a transportation fuel. Suffice to mention the environmental sector, the agriculture and forest industries, as well as the various opportunities to diversify the economy and employment. That is why in early 1991 the federal government created the Interdepartmental
December 10, 1992

Committee on Ethanol with the mandate to develop an action plan aimed at promoting ethanol production and use in Canada.
What would be the impact of this bill on the refining industry? Right now Canadian refineries use an additive called MMT which increases by a point the octane rating of the gasoline they produce. Canada is one of the few countries in the world which prohibits the addition of lead in gasoline in order to meet fuel specifications. Allowing refineries to add MMT to their blends gives them a certain flexibility in their production. On the other hand, American refineries do not use MMT in their unleaded gasoline but mix it with their lead blends, which gives them great flexibility to raise their octane rating.
What would refineries do if all of a sudden, the use of MMT was banned?
In the short term, increasing the severity factor in the refining process would probably be the least costly solution for most refiners. Nevertheless, the additional costs have been estimated at $75 million a year, or about 0.2 cents per litre of gasoline. If the severity index were increased in the refining process, refineries would consume more fuel and produce more carbon dioxide, thus going against our efforts to solve the problem of global warming.
This decision would also slightly increase the amount of benzene and other aromatic compounds in gasoline, which in the long run might not help encourage the use of less polluting fuels. To offset the losses in processing and to meet their fuel requirements, the refineries would need 278,000 cubic metres more crude oil, which would force us to import more oil in years to come.
Nevertheless, this bill does not just seek to eliminate MMT. It would also impose the use of an oxygenated fuel as a component of gasoline. In the United States, the most widely used oxygenated fuels are ethanol and MTBE, an ether produced from methanol and butane. In most cases, MTBE is the cheaper of the two and American refiners use it even without a tax break.
To meet the oxygen content requirements of this bill, we would have to use more MTBE than present gasoline standards allow. If these standards were more flexible, refiners could use MTBE and remove MMT from
Private Members' Business
gasoline without increasing the severity factor in oil refining, as I already explained. Nevertheless, as a result, gasoline production costs would rise by about $300 million a year, or 0.8 cents per litre.
If refiners used ethanol to comply with the oxygen content standards and could meet the demand, they could replace MMT without increasing the severity factor in the refining process. However, this solution would be even costlier than using MTBE, and even taking account of the decision made in the budget to abolish the excise tax on the alcohol portion of mured fuels, the refineries' annual operating costs would increase by $600 million, or about 1.6 cents per litre of gasoline.
Who would pay these costs? The refineries. But given the difficult economic situation of that industry, I expect they will be under strong pressure to pass the bill on to gasoline buyers. Thus Canadian consumers would pay much of the extra cost.
Should consumers be glad to pay the cost of a product that will improve environmental quality? That depends on the balance between product cost and environmental benefits that the consumer can observe around them.
As people have said, we do not know very well how good it will be for the environment to remove MMT from gasoline and impose a very high oxygen content. In some cases, it might improve air quality locally, but in others, air quality might be worse. In fact, it all depends on what environmental problem is being dealt with.
That is one more reason to set gasoline specifications after a thorough technical examination. We must ensure that the proposed changes to the specifications will improve air quality in cities and not worsen it, and that this improvement will benefit consumers in return for the extra costs they will have to pay.
In short, by supporting Bill C-226 moved by my colleague on the other side, we must not encourage the setting of arbitrary specifications that would serve no other purpose than to impose the marketing of ethanol. Instead, we must continue to examine possible changes to various gas blends, as CGSB does, and carry on consultations with the provinces and the automobile and petroleum industries. Finally, we must also maintain the

December 10, 1992
Adjournment Debate
government's ongoing initiatives to stimulate production and use of ethanol.

Mr. Speaker, in late May of this year Vigil, a Toronto-based refugee support group, announced that it would no longer make requests to the minister of immigration to admit refugees on humanitarian and compassionate grounds because, it said, the minister was systematically turning down every such request. This position announced by Vigil was supported by many other refugee support groups working in Canada.
The figures justify what Vigil had said. For example, in the period January 1, 1991 to April 22, 1992 only 23 of 3,485 cases were admitted on the basis of humanitarian and compassionate grounds. For the entire year of 1991, in Quebec only four out of 884 cases were admitted, and in Ontario only 16 out of 2,288 cases were admitted.
What I am talking about is a discretionary power given to the minister in the Immigration Act to admit refugees and other immigrants, especially refugees, who have gone through the process but for one reason or another, despite the merit of their case, it is turned down, either due to mistake, forgotten evidence, the fact that new evidence has come on after the case was heard, error, or whatever.
The power given to the minister to admit cases on humanitarian and compassionate grounds was the last resort given to refugees-I am talking about meritorious refugees, not phoney ones-to have their cases heard and to be granted admission to this country.
I am not talking about the humanitarian and compassionate review which is done at local levels throughout Canada after a refugee's case is turned down by the Immigration and Refugee Board. There is an automatic review at the local level of all cases turned down locally by the Immigration and Refugee Board. I am not talking about that.
In answer to my question on June 2, the minister said that 8,000 had been admitted in 1991. He is talking principally of those cases which are reviewed at the local level. I am talking about the direct appeals to the minister.
On June 2 I asked the minister why he was systematically turning down all these cases, why he was changing the policy under the former minister. That discretionary power had been used with good judgment. He gave me no answer.
During the debate on Bill C-86, the minister announced that he appointed Gordon Fairweather to recommend criteria for the use of that power. I welcomed that announcement, but I want to know today when Mr. Fairweather will report. When will we have these criteria in place and will the minister not use this power in the interim period and those cases that are flagrantly admissible? There are some cases where it is obvious the individual is a refugee but there has been an error. Would the government please at least-

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. parliamentary secretary.

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker,
I have quite a long answer here but I will try to get part of it in on the record.
I would first like to place the question in context of noting that persons who have been refused have already been through a pre-inquiry on humanitarian and compassionate review, the most generous refugee determination process in the world with regard to acceptance rate.
We are interested in offering protection in Canada to those persons who are individually in need of protection. The primary criteria of this post-review was to take place after second level of CRDB refusal. It is to ensure that we do not remove persons who would become a "person of circumstance case" with respect to refugee review climates.
December 10, 1992

As surely good people, we must also consider that over one million people each year inquire about immigration into Canada through a normal process. These decisions are made on a case by case basis, taking into consideration all aspects of the case.
In addition, the government has undertaken as part of Bill C-86 to seek regulatory powers which will allow the creation of special programs on public policy on humanitarian consideration.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very happy to have the opportunity to once again address the issue of the fur industry and the sealing industry.
As you have probably noted in my request to appear again, I am not satisfied with the answers that I received during Question Period and I have asked for an adjournment debate.
I want to deal with the obstacles this industry is currently facing. The economic livelihood, of course, of the Inuit peoples and the people of Newfoundland is being seriously jeopardized by these rather callous and insensitive, mostly foreign financed animal rights campaigns which have unfairly targeted what is left of the sealing and fur industry in this country, an industry which is also sustainable and environmentally friendly and a cultural way of life.
I have asked the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development to make a commitment for the protection of the livelihood of these peoples by launching a counter ad campaign. I feel that would be very effective and would at least send a message out that the fur industry is not up for the abuse of foreign financed organizations which do not really care about the livelihoods of the people of Canada, the original peoples of Canada. 1 urge the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development to make that commitment.
In light of the finance minister's recent economic statement in which we can expect 10 per cent cuts in funding to a number of vital aboriginal programs, I want to stress the importance of this government continuing its commitment to organizations such as Indigenous Survival International and the Fur Industry Defence Program. These organizations provide a voice for the fur industry in this country and also struggle to provide that
Adjournment Debate
Canadian sealers and trappers have the tools they need to struggle for their economic survival.
Last Wednesday the Minister of Finance announced that this government's priority was to build confidence, enhance growth, create jobs and help Canadians take advantage of new opportunities. He also stated that: "Trade is Canada's life-blood".
After almost 400 years, Europe still takes 75 per cent of our wild fur production. The incomes of 100,000 Canadians depend upon access to that market. In 1995 the European Community law will try to end this remarkable trading record by placing severe restrictions on most wild fur exports. If this government is really committed to keeping the Canadian fur trade competitive, the Minister of the Environment together with the Minister for International Trade and Industry, Science and Technology must reaffirm that their departments each will provide the adequate funding needed to complete the trap standards and research work required to satisfy and meet 1995 European Community humane trap requirements.
In addition to this, the Minister of Finance, who says he is committed to helping Canadians take advantage of market opportunities, needs to assure the trappers and sealers in this country that the proper educational and new trap technology training programs and information must be made available. This government must not let three-quarters of our market slip away, never to be regained again.
It is time for this government to take action and make a firm commitment on this national and fast becoming international issue. Mr. Speaker, you and I are both advocates of the fur industry, as I know only too well. We both wear fur publicly and I encourage our leaders and our elected officials to do likewise.
I would also like to say I want to wish all those hard-toiling individuals out on the trapline a very merry Christmas.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to respond to my friend from Western Arctic, particularly in the presence of my friend from Timiskaming who has taken such a lead role in his work with the fur industry over a long period of time. The fur industry is, in fact, Canada's oldest industry. There has been a wild fur industry in this country for over 400 years. The reality is 95 per cent of the Canadian market is in Europe. If we want to continue to trade with Europe we must protect the interests of the constituents of my colleague opposite and from other parts of the

December 10, 1992
Adjournment Debate
Arctic. We must protect the trappers in northern Ontario and other parts of this country, as well as the people of Newfoundland and Labrador who depend so heavily on the seal industry.
We must recognize we have to have a realistic approach in response to the European legislation. Its demands have made it very difficult for our trappers. However the response of government, the fur industry and those who depend so heavily on it has been to sit down and work together. We must ensure we have the proper trapping methods available to all so we comply with European law, but we must also have the skills and tools my hon. colleague talked about available to us.
There has been an extensive amount of training provided to aboriginal peoples and there is a special emphasis on replacing any outmoded equipment. The co-ordination over the last five years has been provided by Indian Affairs and Northern Development. There is a renewed commitment by this government to ensure that program is in place for the next five years to protect those markets and ensure the people of this country who have depended so long and so heavily on the fur industry can do so in the future.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I recently asked a question of the minister of external affairs dealing with David Spencer and Christine Lamont who are in prison in Brazil. The answers I received from both the minister and the Prime Minister have me concerned. They are indicating the request for expulsion would not be automatically granted. I agree with that, but they go further and say it has not been granted in modern times and is not the type of thing that could be utilized. Yet the evidence I have which the justice committee received indicates quite clearly the expulsion order would be expedited quickly and has been granted in the past. In fact, a Chilean was expelled from Brazil just within the year.
There are precedents for this particular remedy under Brazilian law. The Prime Minister, in an excellent response to my question went into great detail. But one thing he said which has me concerned is that Christine Lamont's illness was just a minor thing, a swelling in the legs. From the information we are given, that may well be the case, but in all likelihood something more serious is causing that particular problem. It ranges anywhere from tuberculosis to AIDS. Those are serious matters and I do not think the Prime Minister should simply just cast that away and say: "Well, it is not that serious. It is just a minor thing".
The third thing that really has me concerned is I spoke with the premier of the province of New Brunswick, Frank McKenna who said he had a meeting with the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister assured him he had already requested expulsion and was committed to that. However, when the Prime Minister responded to my question he said that no, that was not the case, that he never made the commitment to the premier. I do not want to get into a fight between the Prime Minister and the premier of New Brunswick, but there is a veiy wide difference between what the Prime Minister is saying and what the premier is saying. I think it is incumbent upon the Prime Minister to clarify his position and clarify just exactly what is going on with respect to the commitment he made to the premier of New Brunswick.
All in all when you translate it, according to the minister's own officials this matter can be dealt with veiy quickly on a state to state level. If a request came from Canada to Brazil, the minister of justice in Brazil promised to expedite the matter just as quickly as it could possibly be done. Many people in Canada and I feel this is an excellent opportunity to get two Canadians back to Canada. No matter whether they are guilty or innocent they have served three years in a Brazilian jail. If they were here in Canada they would probably be eligible for parole. If they were Brazilians they would be eligible for parole. Now we have an opportunity for Canada to intercede on their behalf and bring them back to Canada.
This is the step that we would like to see. For that reason the response of the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for External Affairs is quite frankly unacceptable to the families and to a number of Canadians.
December 10, 1992

It is time that we looked out for these Canadians, as well as other Canadians who are in other jails and who are experiencing similar problems. We have a chance and an opportunity to act on their behalf and we ought to do so.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with care to my hon. friend from Moncton. As he correctly said the Prime Minister did give a very complete answer to this question yesterday. I do not think the Prime Minister would have committed himself to do something that he knew he could not do.
It cannot be assumed that if Canada were to ask for the expulsion of Christine Lamont and David Spencer it would be granted automatically. While the Brazilian president has the discretionary authority to grant expulsion, it has been emphasized to us that there is a clear distinction between the authority, as set out in the Brazilian constitution, and the practice by which that authority is exercised.
We have been told that in practice expulsion would not be granted while appeals are under way or before the convicted prisoner has served his or her sentence. We have also been told that the Brazilian government would not agree to expulsion in these circumstances because it would amount to unwarranted interference by the executive branch of government in the affairs of the judiciary and would discriminate against the other defendants who would not be released or expelled.
The case of the Chilean who was recently expelled from Brazil bears no resemblance to this case. There was no court procedure under way in Brazil in his case, nor was he even in custody. The Chilean authorities wanted him in order to provide information on individuals for whose disappearance during the Pinochet regime he is alleged to have been responsible. This is essentially an extradition case and was handled by expulsion because it is a more rapid procedure.
On many occasions the Secretary of State for External Affairs has expressed concern over the severity of the sentences received by Ms. Lamont and Mr. Spencer. These sentences and the convictions themselves are being appealed in the Brazilian courts. The Canadian embassy in Brasilia has been working actively to ensure that both the appeal of the convictions and the appeal of the sentences move forward as quickly as possible.
Adjournment Debate
Unfortunately, the appeal of the sentences received a set-back on November 30 when the judge ruled that an essential document was missing from the appeal documents, but this ruling was immediately appealed by the lawyers representing Ms. Lamont and Mr. Spencer. The embassy will continue to do everything possible to ensure that the appeal process keeps moving expeditiously.
The embassy's efforts to hasten the ratification of the Transfer of Offenders Treaty between Canada and Brazil, which was signed last July 15, have also been achieving some success. The treaty was approved by the foreign relations committee of the Chamber of Deputies yesterday and we are told that it will be forwarded to the justice committee today.
Finally, I would like to reaffirm that the consulate general in Sao Paulo is doing everything possible to ensure the safety and welfare of Ms. Lamont and Mr. Spencer. Last week when the consulate general learned that Ms. Lamont was suffering from swelling of the ankles it immediately dispatched a Canadian doctor to examine her. After consultations with the prison doctor who had examined her previously and with Ms. Lamont's lawyers arrangements for blood tests at a private facility were made. The consulate general provided sterile syringes for the blood test. It will continue to monitor the situation closely and provide all possible assistance.

Mr. Speaker, last Friday I rose in the House to ask the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture a question with respect to the Crow benefit.
Western Canadian farmers are at a disadvantage in western Canada because they are hundreds of miles from port. In fact, in some cases they are over 1,000 miles from port and have to ship their grain long distances to those ports. The Crow benefit, and before it the Crow rate, has been instrumental in the grain transportation system as we know it in Canada.

December 10,1992
Adjournment Debate
Today, the grain transportation system accounts for tens of thousands of jobs and creates hundreds of millions of dollars for our Canadian economy. When the minister cut the Crow benefit it took $73 million directly out of the pockets of western Canadian producers and put in jeopardy the future of the whole Canadian grain transportation system. In fact, the loss of the Crow benefit will destroy this system unless alternatives are put in place.
The history of agriculture that this government has certainly does not show confidence in this government by the western Canadian producers because it has spent billions of dollars on agriculture in this country but the money has not been spent with any real objective in mind. We still have farmers losing their land, we still have problems in agriculture, we still have rural communities disappearing.
Taxpayers should be upset, farmers should be upset, rural communities should be upset at the waste of money that this government has spent on agriculture. What is even more disparaging is the fact that this money could have been spent much more wisely and with a much greater benefit.
The fact that this government is removing the Crow benefit causes me a lot of concern and causes farmers right across this country a lot of concern. Unless there is something to put in place of the Crow benefit there are going to be grain shipments south. They are going to be going through different ports and our transportation system as we know it is going to disappear.
Right now the St. Lawrence Seaway is in severe difficulty because it is not receiving the grain shipments that it feels it should and it is having financial difficulties. There have already been shipments of grain that have gone through the state of Washington as an experiment. Some of the grain companies are already talking in terms of moving grain south.
It is going to wreak havoc on the economy of western Canada if those procedures continue, if the Crow benefit continues to be reduced and if the Crow benefit disappears. The only reason grain is not moving south right now is the Crow benefit which provides a financial advantage for the farmers to move their grain on the Canadian lines. If the Crow benefit is gone, if the Crow
benefit disappears, what we are then going to see progressively is more and more grain moving south.
Look at the subsidized Mississippi River route that the Americans employ. If somewhere down the road they change their attitude toward subsidies and if the cost goes up we may find ourselves in Canada unable to ship grain via the Canadian route simply because we have not taken into account these alternatives.
I would like to ask the government, at a time when it is reducing the Crow benefit, at a time when it is taking money out of the farmers' pockets, what alternative programs does it have in place? What is its plan? When it reduces the Crow benefit, when it loses the Crow benefit, what is it going to put in place to ensure that we have not only farm families in viable rural communities but a viable and healthy Canadian grain transportation system?

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in considering the impact on agriculture of the economic statement by the Minister of Finance, it is important to examine the whole package of measures.
In seeking the control of the over-all budget, the government is asking many groups to make sacrifices and adjustments. The government has exempted some groups and most important it has exempted the major safety net programs for farmers.
The safety net programs are the core measures through which governments and farmers together have organized to protect farmers against unfavourable markets or production uncertainties. The government recognizes that prices to farmers are among the lowest in history, but that is precisely why we have in place the Gross Revenue Insurance Program, the Net Income Stabilization Accounts, Crop Insurance and the National Tripartite Stabilization Programs. These programs are completely exempt from what the government is asking in other areas.
The over-all impact of reducing the WGTA subsidy by 10 per cent on the well-being of prairie grain producers will be small. At most, it would reduce operating margins by two per cent. What will be much more important will be world market developments and growing conditions in 1993. At the same time, it is estimated that net operating margins of beef and hog producers will increase by about one per cent.
December 10, 1992

The 10 per cent reduction in grants and contributions, including the reduction in the dairy program subsidy, while significant and meaningful, will not put individuals or subsectors at risk. The supply management system provides protection to the dairy sector that is more important and more valuable than a small reduction in the dairy subsidy.
The reintroduction of the 10 per cent investment tax credit for the balance of this year and for all of 1993 will provide significant benefits to farmers on the purchase of new machinery and equipment.
I would like to table the balance of this so that the hon. member can see that we are certainly working with the agricultural community.

Mr. Speaker, last Friday, I asked a question of the minister of aboriginal affairs concerning aboriginal housing.
I note the parliamentary secretary in the House is a faithful attender in the aboriginal affairs committee so he will be aware of the extent of the problem relating to aboriginal housing which the committee has been studying over the last several months.
What prompted my question was that a few days ago the associate deputy minister made a statement in the public accounts committee that of the 70,000 units of aboriginal housing stock in the nation, 35,000 of those units were unliveable. I would like to quote the associate deputy: "Thirty-five thousand units at this stage of the game would be what I call adequate and suitable, liveable in other words".
That statement was so shocking that I decided to bring the issue to the attention of the House during Question Period. When you consider that 35,000 units or half of the existing aboriginal housing stock is unliveable, that there is a backlog of housing units according to the Auditor General of 10,000 to 11,000 units that need to be built and that, when you add in the Bill C-31 requirements for people newly reinstated as aboriginal people under that bill, they require an additional 13,000 units.
The requirement for aboriginal housing stock is 59,000 units. The government is doing virtually nothing to deal with this backlog. The Auditor General's cost estimates, if they are extrapolated to the whole problem, would indicate that the total cost of eliminating the backlog of
Adjournment Debate
aboriginal housing would be $2.1 billion, or half the cost of the government's attack helicopter program. I want to emphasize that that cost is just to deal with the backlog.
My reason for asking the question was to point out that in the financial statement of the Minister of Finance, he did not include aboriginal housing as one of the job creation programs. Rather he included transportation infrastructure and transportation megaprojects.
I want to draw the attention of the House to the fact that if aboriginal housing could be included under the minister's financial statement, it would have created jobs in aboriginal communities where those jobs are desperately needed. It would have created new housing which would have reduced the problems related to overcrowding such as drug abuse, sex abuse, family violence and all of those things that were pointed out by witnesses in our committee were problems with aboriginal housing.
It would have created needed employment in those aboriginal communities because building housing is the most job intensive way of investing capital that a government can do. I hope that the parliamentary secretary will have a positive response as compared to the one given to me by the member for Lincoln when she misled the House by her answer last Friday. I am looking forward to that answer.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to be able to respond on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development.
My colleague from Comox-Alberni makes reference to the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and the work it is doing on a study of aboriginal housing.
A number of the concerns that we are all aware of and some of the ones that he has alluded to are addressed in that report, not the least of which is that there is not enough money. That is clear. Not enough money is something that unfortunately faces all governments in this country, and it comes down to the ability of the government and therefore the society to respond to the need.
Clearly, as the report will point out, there are a number of needs other than just money, not the least of which is the way we deliver the programming and the best way that aboriginal people and aboriginal communities can take advantage of the housing.

December 10, 1992
One of the problems at this point is that to spend money in housing does not in fact provide the local benefit that we would like to see and we think possible. However, I think it is important to recognize that DIAND's responsibility for housing on reserve has led to a commitment that has increased by 34 per cent in the last five years, from $102.7 million to $137.8 million. This fiscal year alone, the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development has budgeted $300 million in direct contributions to First Nations governments. He will also provide about $127 million in guarantees for on reserve housing and CMHC will invest $100 million this year in on reserve housing as well.
Ninety-one per cent of the housing on reserve has brought adequate water service. Seventy per cent of the
Adjournment Debate
current housing stock on reserve has been constructed or renovated in the last 10 years.
As we have discussed and we agree, there was much to be done. One of the things that the department has undertaken is a major study of the housing need itself. There has been a broad consultation with First Nations. The government has spent about $2.5 million on that consultation and held over 250 meetings with a variety of First Nations and their representatives.
